questions.text: What is the obstruction that stops the spleen from falling vertically in a patient whose costal border had splenomegaly measuring 15 cm?
questions.solution:
The phrenicocolic ligament continues below and supports the spleen from the left colic flexure to the thoracic diaphragm opposite the tenth and eleventh ribs.
The phrenicocolic ligament, which marks the location where the colon leaves the peritoneal cavity, is an essential point of junction of abdominal anatomy and, as a result, a key location for the spread of abdominal diseases.

questions.text: An image of a pen test is provided. Identify the nerve being tested?
questions.solution:
Pen test is done to test the median nerve.
The patient is asked to put one hand flat on the table with the palm surface facing upwards, and the patient is asked to touch the pen of the examiner by abducting his thumb. If the patient is not able to abduct his thumb, this means there is median nerve damage.

questions.text: A small boy with multiple humerus fractures, which have resulted in loss of sensation on the lateral side of the forearm, difficulty flexing the elbow, and supination of the forearm. Which nerve is affected?
questions.solution:
Elbow flexion and supination and along with loss of sensation lateral aspect of forearm points to musculocutaneous nerve injury
Roles played by the nerve:
  • Motor functions – muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm which include coracobrachialis, biceps brachii and the brachialis
  • Sensory functions – gives rise to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, which innervates the lateral aspect of the forearm, mentioned in the question.
  • These muscles flex the upper arm at the shoulder and the elbow. In addition, the biceps brachii also supinates the forearm.



Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 925

questions.text:
A little child was admitted to the hospital by his father due to a fever, a low backache, and chronic hip flexion.
He has already experienced spine TB. The infant has an inguinal swelling upon inspection. Which indicated muscle is likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: a
 
  • The inguinal swelling in the image is caused by the psoas abscess extending into the inguinal canal.
  • The psoas major muscle is the most likely muscle to be involved in this case because it is the muscle that is most affected by psoas abscess.
  • Psoas abscess is most commonly caused by infection from the spine, such as from spine TB.
  • The infection can spread to the psoas major muscle through the intervertebral foramina.
   



Reference-: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery Edition 28 th Page No 1104

questions.text: A patient is experiencing vision problems. Examination revealed an aneurysm in an artery at the base of the brain that was compressing the optic chiasma. What is the involved vessel?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Anterior communicating artery
 
  • The anterior communicating artery is an artery that connects the two anterior cerebral arteries at the base of the brain. It forms part of the circle of Willis, which is a circular arrangement of arteries that provides collateral blood flow to the brain.
  • The ACA supplies blood to the anterior part of the brain, including the optic chiasma.
  • An aneurysm of the ACA can compress the optic chiasma, causing vision problems.

Following the GSV collection for CABG, saphenous neuralgia is prevalent.

questions.text: Which is the last structure encountered during the lumbar puncture?
questions.solution:
Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous and interspinous ligaments, ligamentum flavum, epidural space containing the internal spinal venous plexus, dura, arachnoid, and lastly the subarachnoid space are all punctured by the lumbar puncture needle in that order.

questions.text: In chronic kidney disease, what is the acid-base abnormality?
questions.solution:
CKD causes Metabolic acidosis (option 2) by the following mechanisms - 

1. Decreased Excretion of Hydrogen Ions:
The kidneys are responsible for excreting excess H⁺ ions into the urine. In CKD, there is a reduction in the number of functioning nephrons, which decreases the kidney's capacity to excrete these ions. As a result, H⁺ accumulates in the bloodstream, leading to acidosis.

2. Impaired Bicarbonate Reabsorption:
Normally, the kidneys reabsorb bicarbonate from the urine. In CKD, the reabsorption capacity is impaired, leading to a decrease in serum bicarbonate levels. This results in a reduced buffering capacity for H⁺ ions in the blood.

3. Loss of Ammonium Excretion:
The kidneys also produce ammonium (NH₄⁺) as a means of excreting H⁺ ions. In CKD, the ability to synthesize and excrete ammonia is diminished, leading to less H⁺ excretion and further acid retention.
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 83

questions.text: When a person is given ORS, what is the receptor for glucose absorption in the GIT?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: SGLT1

ORS is composed of-


 
  • The main aim of ORS is to provide fluid and electrolytes to the body in case of diarrhoea.
  • The Na+/glucose cotransporter SGLT1 is an active pump that transports two sodium ions and one glucose molecule together across the cell membrane. ORSs include both sodium and glucose because, without glucose, intestinal sodium is not actively absorbed.
  • It should be noted that glucose does not co-transport water - rather it is the now increased relative concentration of Na+ across the intestinal wall which pulls water through after it

Glucose transporters and their location-

questions.text: A 58-year-old man was taken to the emergency room with confusion and lethargy. His body temperature is 36.7°C, blood pressure is 86/58 mmHg, heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and respirations are 10 beats per minute. pCO2 is 49 mmHg, pH is 7.59, and pO2 is 85 mmHg. Which of the following conditions best describes his acid-base status?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Metabolic alkalosis

Method to calculate the acid base status is as follows
  1. We need 3 values to find out the answer. They are pH, pCO2 and HCO3
  2. The pCO2 value correlates with respiratory status
HCO3 value correlates with metabolic status
  1. Normal values are pH = 7.4     PCO2 = 40      HCO3 = 24

 
  1. Step 1 : pH <7.4 = acidosis
              pH >7.4 = alkalosis
  1. Step 2 : we have to find out if it is respiratory or metabolic
              If pCO2 indicates acidosis and pH indicates acidosis – Respiratory acidosis
              If pCO2 indicates alkalosis and pH indicates alkalosis – Respiratory alkalosis
              If HCO3 indicates acidosis and pH indicates acidosis – Metabolic acidosis
              If HCO3 indicates alkalosis and pH indicates alkalosis – Metabolic alkalosis

Another method is to remember ROME “RESPIRATORY OPPOSITE METABOLIC EQUAL



In this question pH is 7.59 which means alkalosis. pCO2 is 49 mmHg which indicates acidosis. Since the respiratory quotient is not correlating with alkalosis it seems to be a compensatory mechanism to overcome metabolic alkalosis.


In this question pH is 7.59 which means alkalosis. pCO2 is 49 mmHg which indicates acidosis. Since the respiratory quotient is not correlating with alkalosis it seems to be a compensatory mechanism to overcome metabolic alkalosis.

If we use the ROMS( Respiratory opposite Metabolic Same) mnemonic pH and pCO2 are both increasing which indicates metabolic alkalosis.



 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 705,635

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man needed dialysis, so he went to the hospital. An arterial blood sample was collected for testing prior to sending him for dialysis.
Which of the laboratory results listed below indicates compensated metabolic acidosis?
1. Low PCO2, normal bicarbonate and, high pH
2. Low PCO2, low bicarbonate, low pH
3. High PCO2, high bicarbonate and, low pH
4. High PCO2, low bicarbonate and High PH
questions.solution:
With or without a compensatory drop in bicarbonate (HCO3), respiratory alkalosis is characterised by a primary fall in carbon dioxide partial pressure (Pco2); pH may be high or close to normal. An increase in respiratory volume or rate (hyperventilation), or both, is the cause. Acute or chronic respiratory alkalosis is possible.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same



 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 705,706,635

questions.text:
A young woman is discovered unconscious after taking an undetermined amount of sleeping pills at an undetermined hour.
The following results are obtained from an arterial blood sample: pH 7.10, HCO2 32 meq/liter, and pCO2 68 mmHg.
Which of the following statements best sums up this patient's acid-base condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Respiratory acidosis with partial renal compensation

Step 1 : pH is 7.10 which indicates acidosis
Step 2 : pCO2 is 68 mmHg I.e higher than normal  which means respiratory acidosis
Step 3 : HCO3 is raised suggesting metabolic compensation
Therefore the answer will be Respiratory acidosis with partial renal compensation.

In case of metabolic acidosis, Winters Formula is used to calculate the required pCO2 compensation
Winters formula predicted PaCO2 = 1.5 x [HCO3-] + 8

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 635,636

questions.text: A patient complains of breathing difficulties and widespread weakness. A mid-diastolic murmur with pronounced "a" waves is audible on auscultation in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: TS (Tricuspid stenosis)

The symptoms given such as breathing difficulty and weakness along with a mid diastolic murmur with pronounced “a” waves is definitive of TS.
  • The narrowing of the tricuspid valve impedes blood flow, leading to several symptoms such as fatigue, shortness of breath (especially during physical activity), palpitations, abdominal discomfort, and edema. In severe cases, tricuspid stenosis can cause heart failure.
  • A mid diastolic murmur is a characteristic feature of mitral stenosis but is seen in both mitral as well as tricuspid stenosis.
  • MDM + dyspnea suggests left sided defect like MS
MDM + edema suggests Right sided defect like TS
  • In this case, even though patient is presenting with MDM + dyspnea, a classical prominent “a” wave is seen on jvp which strongly suggests TS as the right answer.
A small table to remember in valvular heart diseases is as follows-



JVP waveforms and the abnormalities associated with them-

  • Arthritis

questions.text: A middle-aged farmer produced maize primarily as a staple crop. He appears before the OPD as depicted in the picture. He also complains of having diarrhea. Which vitamin deficiency is evident?
questions.solution:
Diarrhea, dermatitis (lesions on the neck), and a maize-rich diet - all point towards Niacin deficiency (option 1) also known as Pellagra.
It is caused by a lack of dietary niacin or its precursor, the amino acid tryptophan. A maize (corn) diet is one possible cause of pellagra, due to its low tryptophan content and hence, low conversion to niacin in the body causing niacin deficiency and symptoms of Pellagra

questions.text:
In a student-run experiment on ETC, the addition of pyruvate and one inhibitor prevented oxidative phosphorylation from occurring.
Which inhibitor did the student most likely use?
questions.solution:
Oligomycin completely blocks oxidation and phosphorylation by blocking the flow of protons through ATP synthase.
 

Here’s a table showing the Electron Transport Chain (ETC) complexes and their blockers:

Step/Complex Enzyme/Function Blockers Effect
Complex I NADH: Ubiquinone Oxidoreductase Rotenone, Amytal, Piericidin A Inhibits electron transfer from NADH to CoQ
Complex II Succinate Dehydrogenase Malonate (competitive inhibitor) Blocks FADH₂ oxidation, reducing CoQ flow
Complex III Cytochrome bc₁ Complex Antimycin A Blocks transfer of electrons to Cytochrome c
Complex IV Cytochrome c Oxidase Cyanide, Carbon monoxide (CO), Azide Prevents transfer of electrons to oxygen
ATP Synthase (Complex V) F₀F₁ ATP Synthase Oligomycin Inhibits ATP production
Uncouplers Disrupt proton gradient DNP, FCCP, Thermogenin ATP synthesis stops, but O₂ consumption increases

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 127.

questions.text: Which amino acid should be supplemented in a patient with cystathionine B synthase deficiency?
questions.solution:
Because Cystathioninase helps break down Cystathionine into Cysteine and Homoserine.
Because cysteine cannot be generated when cystathionine beta synthase is deficient, cysteine must be added to the diet as a supplement.

questions.text:
A Patient presented with generalised fatigue, tiredness. Primary clinical examination was normal . Normal TLC and DLC.No immature cells were seen on PS. Superficial discrete lymph nodes were enlarged. On biopsy, it showed an effaced architecture,  atypical cells containing indented nucleus, prominent nucleolus. CD 10 and BCL 2 were Positive.
What’s the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Follicular lymphoma
 
  • By performing a biopsy, which involves removing all or part of an enlarged lymph node and studying the cells under a microscope, the diagnosis of follicular lymphoma is confirmed.
  • In FL instances, CD10 expression is present. Follicles showed a significant positive trend. One CD10-positive instance of FL displayed ambiguous BCL2 staining, while the other did not.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 599.

questions.text:
Red cell aplasia was diagnosed in a patient with a substernal mass who was not responding to blood transfusion. Hb is low; TLC is normal.
What is the most probable cause of aplasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Is (Option 3) Thymic neoplasia
 
  • Thymic neoplasia is the most probable cause.
  • Pure Red Cells Aplasia is believed to be an autoimmune condition that may be brought on by a thymus gland tumor, some medications, or a viral infection. It belongs to a class of disorders that cause bone marrow failure.
  • Pure Red Cells Aplasia is also seen in Parvo virus B19 infection and Diamond-Blackfan syndrome. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 633.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female patient has a PAP Smear with hyperchromatic nuclei and poor maturation index pleomorphism that affects nearly all thickness. What is the name of this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Dysplasia
 
  1. Metaplasia: Metaplasia is a reversible process in which one type of adult cell is replaced by another type of adult cell that is not typical for that tissue. This adaptive change occurs in response to chronic irritation or inflammation and is meant to protect the underlying tissues from the adverse environment. For example, in the respiratory tract of smokers, the normal ciliated columnar epithelial cells may be replaced by stratified squamous epithelial cells.
  2. Hyperplasia: Hyperplasia is an increase in the number of cells in an organ or tissue, resulting in its enlargement. In epithelium it may be seen as increased thickness.
  3. Carcinoma: Dysplasia with basement membrane invasion
  4. Dysplasia: It is a loss in the uniformity of individual cells and in their architectural orientation. Dysplastic cells exhibit considerable pleomorphism and often possess hyperchromatic nuclei that are abnormally large for the size of the cell. Mitotic figures are more abundant than usual and frequently appear in abnormal locations within the epithelium.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 7.

questions.text:
A patient who arrived with exhaustion, weight loss, and illness has a 20-year history of exposure to benzene.
Systematic analysis is typical. Which cancer is the most likely to be present in him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Blood
 
  • Blood cancer will be suspected in the given patient.
  • Anemia may result from benzene's damaging effects on the bone marrow and possible reduction in red blood cell production. Moreover, it can weaken the immune system and produce excessive bleeding, which increases the risk of infection.
Remember Benzene - AML vs Benzidene - Bladder Cancer
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 659.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who had migrating arthritis of the lower big joints and tachycardia appeared. Murmur is Pansystolic. Mitral regurgitation is seen on an echo. What does the biopsy reveal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Aschoff body
 
  • Upon performing a cardiac catheterization, an endomyocardial biopsy revealed the presence of an Aschoff's body in the endocardium, confirming a clinical suspicion of active carditis.
  • Aschoff bodies are nodules that are discovered in the hearts of rheumatic fever patients. They are a defining feature of rheumatic heart disease and are caused by inflammation in the heart muscle.

Fig: Microscopic appearance of an Aschoff body

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman working in IT visited the OPD complaining of light weariness. She explains that she has a history of spending 12 to 14 hours every day in front of a computer. She typically orders non-vegetarian food with less fruits and vegetables from a restaurant. A blood test revealed Hb was 9g% and MCV was 120. What is the most likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Folic Acid deficiency
 
  • The 30-year-old woman working in IT complains of light weariness, and her blood test reveals low hemoglobin (9g%) and an elevated mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 120.
  • The most likely cause of her condition is folic acid deficiency.
  • Folic acid is essential for DNA synthesis and red blood cell production.
  • Prolonged computer use and a diet lacking in fruits and vegetables contribute to folic acid deficiency.
  • The deficiency leads to impaired DNA synthesis, resulting in ineffective red blood cell maturation and macrocytic anemia.
* [Extra Edge]: Vitamins



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 653.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with cirrhosis. Eosinophilic material that was cytokeratin-positive during the liver biopsy was CK 8+ and CK 18+. What is it most likely composed of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Intermediate
 
  • Patients with chronic alcoholism and purulent destructive pulmonary diseases have been found to have an accumulation of intermediate filaments in their lung macrophages and endotheliocytes.
  • In liver accumulation of cytokeratin 8 and 18 is known as Malory Denk Body. 
  • Cytoskeletal components that build up excessively are an indication of cell dystrophy.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 837.

questions.text: Where is a mismatch repair defect seen?
questions.solution:
DNA mismatch repair (MMR) gene mutations in the germline are the primary cause of the prevalent inherited form of neoplasia known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC). Human exonuclease 1 is one of the proteins that MMR proteins have been shown to bind with (hEXO1).

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 380.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy shows up with bleeding gums and is easily bruised. He had  Hb 3g/dL, TLC 15,000/mm3, and a platelet count of 15000/mm3 after a month of fever. Upon examination, there was pallor and a petechial rash all over the body. No spleen. No immature cells are visible in the peripheral smear. No Macrocytes, no megakaryocytes, and depleted bone marrow is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Idiopathic Acquired Aplastic anemia
 
  • The 20-year-old boy presents with bleeding gums, easy bruising, severe anemia (Hb 3g/dL), low platelet count (15,000/mm3), pallor, and a petechial rash. The most likely diagnosis is idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia.
  • This condition is characterized by bone marrow failure, resulting in pancytopenia (low red blood cells, low white blood cells, and low platelets).
  • The absence of immature cells, macrocytes, and megakaryocytes in the peripheral smear, as well as depleted bone marrow, further support this diagnosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 660.

questions.text:
A patient is diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung. During the pulmonectomy, there was a 1 cm blackish hilar lymph node.
Identify the cause of pigmentation.
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 2) Anthracotic pigment.
 
  • The patient with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung had a 1 cm blackish hilar lymph node observed during pulmonectomy. The cause of pigmentation in this case is anthracotic pigment.
  • Anthracotic pigment refers to the accumulation of carbonaceous particles in the tissues, typically derived from inhaled environmental pollutants or cigarette smoke.
  • Chronic exposure to these particles can lead to their deposition in the lymph nodes, resulting in pigmentation.
  • In the context of squamous cell carcinoma of the lung, the pigmentation is most likely due to the accumulation of carbon particles from inhaled smoke or other environmental sources in the regional lymph nodes.
* [Extra Edge]: PNEUMOCONIOSIS


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 694.

questions.text: A multiple sclerosis diagnosis is made for a patient. Where is the disease most prevalent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Oligodendrocytes
 
  • In multiple sclerosis (MS), the disease is most prevalent in oligodendrocytes.
  • Oligodendrocytes are responsible for producing myelin, the protective covering around nerve fibers in the central nervous system.
  • In MS, the immune system mistakenly attacks and damages the myelin, leading to communication problems between the brain and the rest of the body.
  • Oligodendrocyte damage and loss of myelin are characteristic features of MS lesions.
  • The disease primarily affects the white matter of the brain and spinal cord, where oligodendrocytes are abundant.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1269.

questions.text:
A patient who has been receiving long-term steroids for recurring eczema and chronic urticaria is now visiting the clinic with itching and nocturnal cough.
Alveolar lavage for bronchospasm revealed several tiny larvae. What is your medical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's use of steroids, according to the query, suggests that his immune system is impaired. Disseminated Strongyloidiasis, a serious infection caused by Strongyloides stercoralis, is known to occur in immunocompromised persons. The larvae of this creature are found in many bodily organs, which defines it.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 183.

questions.text: Identify the parasite whose microflariae have a sheath at the end without a nucleus.
questions.solution:
Wuchereria Bancrofti is the correct option.
It has a short neck that gives the appearance of being constricted, which connects the short cephalic or head region to the main body. With no nuclei at the tail tip, the dark patches have scattered nuclei throughout the body cavity.

Mnemonic trick: -
Love full- Loa Loa many nuclei at tail tip
Wedding nil- Wuchheria no nuclei at tail tip
Left is Brugia so it has 2 nuclei at tail tip


Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 209.

The given clinical scenario is of Syphilis. Dark Field microscopy is used for spirochetes.

questions.text:
There was a brucellosis suspicion regarding a patient. A sample of serum was sent for a routine agglutination test. When the sample was diluted, the test result changed from negative to positive.
What might have caused the original negative test results?
questions.solution:
Antibody overproduction occurs in the prozone. Due to their modest size, the immunological complexes generated in this zone are challenging to find. IgG, IgA, and IgM antibodies are discovered using the Standard Agglutination Test. 48 hours are spent incubating the sample at 37 degrees Celsius.
A titre of 1:160 or higher is regarded as important. Prozone phenomenon and the presence of insufficient or blocking antibodies are both associated with false negative SAT.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 111.

questions.text: A 11-year-old boy is diagnosed with skin rashes after developing bluish-white patches in the buccal mucosa. The genome of the organism that caused the problem is:
questions.solution:
The patient is most probably suffering from an infection of measles, caused by a SS enveloped RNA virus.
Structure of Measles virus-
The tubelike, helically symmetrical nucleocapsid contains a monopartite, single-stranded, negative-sense RNA genome and an RNA-directed RNA polymerase. The nucleocapsid associates with the matrix protein (M) at the base of a double-layered lipid envelope.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 518.

questions.text: Late at night, a group of friends got together for a celebration and had pastries from a bakery. Early that morning, everyone started vomiting. Choose the organism that is most likely to be the cause.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3:  Staph aureus

Food poisoning caused by consuming bakery products and the one that is manifested in around 6-9 hours is mostly indicative of staphylococcus aureus-mediated food poisoning. It is manifested as vomiting and diarrhoea with the absence of fever.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 204.

questions.text: An X-ray of a known AIDS individual with a productive cough and fever revealed consolidation in the right intralobar area, along with CD 4 counts of 55 per microliter. What is the most commonly cited reason for this?
questions.solution:
In an individual with AIDS, especially with a CD4 count of 55 per microliter and symptoms like a productive cough and fever, the most commonly cited reason for pneumonia in this context is 4. Pneumocystis jirovecii.

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) is a common opportunistic infection in patients with advanced HIV/AIDS and is characterized by specific radiographic findings such as consolidation or ground-glass opacities.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 226.

questions.text: 70% of the patient's body had burned. A sample that was taken from the burn site was tested for the presence of an obligate aerobe, which is thought to be the likely culprit. What exactly is the microbe?
questions.solution:
In burn patient care settings, invasive burn wound sepsis caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a substantial concern.
Typically a low invasiveness and pathogenicity organism, PSEUDOMONAS AERUGINOSA (Bacillus pyocyaneus) is usually observed as a local dweller of burns, surgical sites, and the genitourinary tract. Yet, this gram-negative, motile rod can act as a potentially fatal infection when the right host conditions are present.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 320.

questions.text: Which of the following is utilized for blood spill management?
questions.solution:
• Chlorine-based compounds  - in particular - Sodium hypochlorite are used in blood spill management.
  • It is usually diluted in water depending on its intended use.
  • "Strong chlorine solution" - 0.5% solution of hypochlorite (~ 5000 ppm free chlorine) is used for large blood spills. Such solutions have been demonstrated to inactivate both Clostridium difficile and HPV,
Option a) Chlorhexidine (hibitane) : This is one of the most useful skin antiseptics. Highly active against vegetative gram-positive organisms, and moderately active against gram-positive microbes.
Option b) Formaldehyde: it is a highly toxic gas effective against vegetative bacteria,fungi and many viruses but only slowly effective against bacterial spores. It is most commonly used for disinfection of rooms, may also be used for disinfection of blankets, beds, books and other articles which cannot be boiled.
Option c) Ethyl alcohol: Is most commonly used for skin disinfection and hand washing. It is potent bactericides, fungicidal, virucidal and tuberculocidal but does not destroy bacterial spores.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 145.

questions.text: A little boy complained of abdominal ache and bloody stools. Identify the culture medium for the causal organism in the provided image.
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture suggests the diagnosis if Shigellosis which can be confirmed by using Selenite F broth for culture.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 294.

questions.text: Bronchial asthmatic patient developed glaucoma. Which medication from the list below will be administered to this patient for OAG?
questions.solution:
Latanoprost is the drug of choice in the given scenario.
  • In situations of POAG and a history of bronchial asthma, beta blockers are contraindicated because they further constrict the airways and exacerbate asthma.
  • In patients with asthma who have never taken corticosteroids before, latanoprost therapy has no effect on resting or triggered airway function or asthma symptoms. Patients with glaucoma and concurrent bronchial asthma may benefit from latanoprost treatment.
  • Carboprost, Gemeprost, Alprostadil are not indicated in the treatment of glaucoma.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1121, 1123.

choices.text: Dosing rate = Vd x Target Plasma Concentration
Dosing rate = CL x Target Plasma Concentration

questions.text: Drug administration and elimination rates are equal. How will you determine the drug's dosing rate to keep the concentration at a constant state?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Dosing rate = CL x Target Plasma Concentration

The formula for drug dosing rate is clearance x plasma concentration.

*Steady-state concentration (Css) = F x Dosing rate/ CL
  • where dosing rate is the dose per time interval and is dose/T
  • F is the fractional bioavailability, CL is clearance.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 40.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient who has been using low-dose aspirin for the past six months was diagnosed with rectal haemorrhage. Which of the following substances is likely to be inhibited and cause the bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Thromboxane A2
 
  • Aspirin is an irreversible inhibitor of the COX (cyclooxygenase enzyme). Aspirin at low doses (75mg) primarily acts by inhibiting cyclooxygenase 1 (COX-1).
  • Low-dose aspirin, used for antiplatelet action, results in selective inhibition of platelet COX-1 (thromboxane synthase) inhibiting its ability to form thromboxane A2 (needed for platelet aggregation).
  • At higher doses, aspirin also inhibits COX-2 and results in decreased production of prostacyclin from endothelium. This may nullify the beneficial anti-aggregatory effect of aspirin.
  • Side effects: Gastric ulceration, tinnitus (CN VIII). Chronic use can lead to acute renal failure, interstitial nephritis, GI bleeding. Risk of Reye syndrome in children treated with aspirin for viral infection. Toxic doses cause respiratory alkalosis early, but transitions to mixed metabolic acidosis-respiratory alkalosis.
* [ Extra Edge ]: Mechanism of Actions 
 

 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 215.

questions.text:
A more recent monoclonal antibody used to treat rheumatoid arthritis is tocilizumab.
It is effective against:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) IL-6
 
  • A new monoclonal antibody called tocilizumab blocks interleukin-6 (IL-6) from binding to its receptor in a competitive manner (IL-6R).
  • To stop IL-6 signal transduction to inflammatory mediators that call for B and T cells, the complete receptor complex must be inhibited. A nonlinear pharmacokinetic profile characterises tocilizumab.
  • Those with RA who do not react to methotrexate or other disease-modifying antirheumatic medications may find it helpful.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 782.

questions.text: The way that methotrexate works to treat osteosarcoma is as follows:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Competitive inhibitor of DHFR

Drug Class Mechanism of Action (MOA)
Methotrexate Antimetabolite Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), blocking the conversion of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate. This disrupts DNA synthesis and cell division, especially in rapidly dividing cells like cancer or immune cells.
 This principle is thus used in the management of carcinoma like Osteosarcoma.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 214.

questions.text: Which of the following should not be administered concurrently to a patient who is taking metronidazole?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Alcohol

  • Metronidazole cannot be given because it produces disulfiram like reaction.
  • Oxidation of acetaldehyde is inhibited by disulfiram, a drug that has been used to deter drinking by patients with alcohol dependence.
  • When ethanol is consumed in the presence of disulfiram, acetaldehyde accumulates and causes an unpleasant reaction of facial flushing, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and headache.
Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 398.

questions.text: Digoxin was being taken by an AF patient. Aspirin, KCl, Triamterene, and Clarithromycin were the first medications he received. Digoxin's serum concentration increases from 2.5 mg/dl to 3.4 mg/dl. ECG thickening of the T waves is the problem. Which medication among the following is to blame for the rise in digoxin levels in the serum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Clarithromycin
 
  • MDR1 (P-Glycoprotein) is expressed on the brush border membrane of renal epithelia, and its function can be monitored using digoxin (>70% excreted in the urine).
  • MDR1 inhibitors (e.g., quinidine, verapamil, valspodar, spironolactone, clarithromycin, and ritonavir) all markedly reduce renal excretion of digoxin.
  • This means that more of the drug Digoxin is present in the body for a longer period of time, which can increase the risk of Digoxin toxicity.
Option1, 2 and 3 Drugs have no enzyme induction or inhibition action significant to Digoxin Metabolism.

* Symptoms of Digoxin toxicity can include,
- Anorexia, nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain are usually reported first, are due to gastric irritation, mesenteric vasoconstriction and CTZ stimulation.
- Almost every type of arrhythmia can be produced by digoxin, pulsus bigeminies is common; others are nodal and ventricular extrasystoles, ventricular tachycardia and terminally ventricular fibrillation.

Drugs that can cause digoxin toxicity (P glycoprotein/MDR 1 inhibitors) are remembered  as CAVE Q drugs. These include:   

Drugs
C - Clarithromycin, Cyclosporine
A - Amiodarone
V - Verapamil
E - Erythromycin
Q - Quinine/Quinidine

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 91.

questions.text:
A teenage girl using sulfonamides reported having stomach ache and seizures.
The most likely reason is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Acute intermittent porphyria

The given clinical vignette describes the condition called Acute Intermittent Porphyria.

* CLINICAL FEATURES: - [ MNEMONIC – 5P]
  • Pain in abdomen
  • Port wine colored Pee
  • Polyneuropathy
  • Psychological Disturbance
* PRECIPITATING FACTORS: -
It is precipitated by factors which increase the activity of ALA Synthase enzyme (Eg : CYP450 inducers, alcohol, starvation)
Sulfonamide is an example of CYP450 inducer drug.



* MNEMONIC: - 
GRABS Priyanka Chopra for a QUICK VEG Dinner
-GRABS Priyanka Chopra – INDUCERS
-QUICK VEG Dinner – INHIBITORS 

*CONGENITAL ERYTHROPOETIC PORPHYRIA: - Characterized by blisters. Also known as Gunther Disease / Erythrodontia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 757.

choices.text: Alprazolam 1/2 mg one tab HS for 7 days
Alprazolam 0.5mg one tab at bedtime for 7 days

questions.text: How would you correctly prescribe Alprazolam if you were a medical professional?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Alprazolam 0.5mg one tab at bedtime for 7 days

Abbreviations like OD(once a day) or HS(at bedtime/before sleep) are to be avoided in prescriptions. More over dose of medicine is written in decimal not in fraction.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 1146.

questions.text: Recognize the injury in the given image:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Incised looking laceration
 
  • The given picture shows an incised looking lacerated wound.
  • On the patient's forehead, the indicated wound is visible. Due to the sheering pressures on the skin, despite the uneven edges, the laceration seems to be incised.
  • Similar injuries are also possible on the shin area.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 190.

questions.text: Did you see that Mr. "A" killed Mr. "B"?" was the question the attorney posed to the witness while they were documenting the evidence in a courtroom. Witness responded, "Yes." This kind of inquiry is accepted in?
questions.solution:
Leading questions are allowed during cross examination of the witness. Leading questions are questions which have answer in yes or no. 

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 14.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female who had previously overdosed on cocaine arrived at the emergency room.
What sign in this person is least likely to be present?
questions.solution:
This person overdosed on cocaine. Vasoconstriction is the primary effect of cocaine. The heart rate goes up as a result. Rhythm of breathing and blood pressure.

Moreover, it results in "Cocaine Fever" an increase in body temperature.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 602.

questions.text: What is this poison's active ingredient?
questions.solution:
The nut shown in the given picture is Marking Nut or Semecarpus Anacardium. Also known as Bhilawa.
The two active principles in this are Bhilawanol and Semecarpol.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 557.

questions.text: Which of the following statement about the changes shown in the below graphic is true?
questions.solution:
Above image shows Marbling seen in putrefaction.
When bacteria spreads through blood vessels it causes conversion of haemoglobin into sulphaemoglobin which imparts a greenish or reddish-brown staining of inner walls of superficial vessels.
It is seen as linear branching pattern which gives a marbled or road map like appearance. It first appears in shoulder, roots of the limbs, etc. It is seen 36 to 48 hours after death.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 166.

choices.text: Case of immersion in water for 36 hours

questions.text: What causes the below phenomenon?
questions.solution:
This example of prolonged submersion in water (over 36 hours) is marked by skin mottling and a greenish black discoloration brought on by putrefactive alterations.

This picture is also referred to as ‘Washerwoman feet’, a non-specific sign of drowning.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 368.

questions.text: Twins are born to a married lady. The husband orders a paternity test since he doesn't believe he is the father. He is the father of one child, but not the other, according to the test. This is:
questions.solution:
Superfecundation
  • Since they are twins, it means the babies were conceived in the same menstrual cycle.
 
  • Superfetation involves two embryos that form during two separate menstrual cycles.
 
  • With superfecundation, there is Fertilization of two or more ova in different intercourses in same menstrual cycle
  • Superfecundation can occur in humans but superfetation doesn't occur. 



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 840.

questions.text: A naked person was enjoying himself while sitting on a balcony overlooking a packed park. This paraphilia is referred to as:
questions.solution:
Exhibitionism refers to the display of private parts in public. It is punishable under section 294 IPC.
Masochism involves giving pain to others
Fetishism is the sexual gratification which is obtained from inanimate objects belonging to the opposite gender.
Stalking is following a female physically or digitally, in spite of clear prior disinterest shown by the female.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 433.

questions.text: A toddler ate an unidentified fruit. He eventually developed signs of photophobia, heated skin, inability to pass urine, restlessness, irritation, and bewilderment. Choose the poison and remedy.
questions.solution:
This case of datura poisoning demonstrates the effects of high atropine levels. Due to the fact that neostigmine cannot pass the blood brain barrier, physostigmine is the preferred antidote.
The anticholinesterase drug physostigmine raises acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 598.

questions.text:
33-year-old female complaining of blurred vision in the right halves of both eyes.
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Left optic tract
  • Injury to the left optic tract will lead to right sided homonymous hemianopia i.e blurring of right halves of both eyes.
  • Left Optic tract contains nasal fibers of the right side and temporal fibers of the left side, which are involved in this lesion.

VISUAL FIELD DEFECTS: 




Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 5th edition, Page no 325, 326.

questions.text: What keeps the cornea transparent?
questions.solution:
Correct option ia 3: Keratan Sulphate.
 
  • Keratan sulphate is found in the cornea and plays a critical role in maintaining corneal transparency. 
  • It is involved in the structural organization of the corneal matrix and contributes to the clarity of the cornea.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 156.

questions.text:
A female comes with H/O contact lens use comes with following. What is the diagnosis?

1 .Trachoma
2. GPC
3. Spring Cataract
4. Acute follicular conjunctivitis
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: GPC.
 
  • The severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis is known as giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC).
  • It is most frequently encountered with contact lens (CL) wear; in such cases, it is termed contact lens-associated papillary conjunctivitis (CLPC). 
  • It may be caused by ocular prostheses, exposed sutures, and scleral buckles, corneal surface irregularity, or filtering blebs.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 194.

questions.text: A one-month-old baby is diagnosed as having photophobia and watery eyes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Watering of eyes along with photophobia and blue sclera in a one-month old child is suggestive of congenital glaucoma. 

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG)/Buphthalmos is a rare condition caused by genetically defined defects in the trabecular meshwork and anterior chamber angle, which result in high intraocular pressure (IOP), but no other ocular or systemic developmental problems. It is seen between birth and the age of 3-4 years.

Clinical features:

● The affected eye is enlarged with a hazy cornea.
● Increased size of eyeball (Buphthalmos).
● Photophobia is the earliest symptoms due to corneal edema
● It should be noted that the earliest sign is Corneal Haze (Ground glass appearance)
● Watering of eyes
● At a later stage, due to rupture of Descemet's membrane, more discrete corneal opacities are seen
● Blue eyes due to scleral thinning.


 
Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1106, 1107.

questions.text: Despite having myopic astigmatism, a 15-year-old girl rejects her glasses. What may be recommended?
questions.solution:
No Refractive surgery for myopic astigmatism- not even ICL is recommended below the age of 18 years. Hence the correct option is option (4) None in this question. 



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 52-55.

questions.text: An elderly female with gradual painless DOV fundus findings image :
questions.solution:
The given picture shows hard exudates as seen in Diabetic Retinopathy.

A potentially dangerous side effect of macular edema in people with diabetes mellitus is the development of hard macular exudates. They develop in the Outer plexiform layer of the retina. Hard foveal exudate deposition, one of the most prevalent and early clinical indications of diabetic retinopathy, has been linked to visual impairment.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 544, 545.

questions.text: A youngster that underwent enucleation and had a whitish pupillary reflex exhibits the Flexner Winter Steiner Rosette. What is the most probable  diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Flexner wintersteiner rosettes are seen in cases of retinoblastoma. Presence of leukocoria, i.e. white eye relfex also confirms the diagnosis.
The most frequent intraocular cancer in children and infants, accounting for 3% of all paediatric malignancies, is retinoblastoma. The RB1 gene, also known as a tumour suppressor gene, is the cause of it.

Image shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes—arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent “lumen”.






Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 349.
Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1325.

questions.text: DOV under low-light conditions, accompanied with dry eyes and ocular surface abrasion. Which deficiency is related?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin A (Retinoic acid) deficiency can cause dry eye illness. Mild deficiency causes conjunctival alterations and a severe deficiency leads to xerophthalmia
  • Night blindness/Nyctalopia or DOV under low light conditions is the earliest symptom of Vitamin A deficiency.
  • Retinoic acid formulations are applied topically and taken orally to treat this problem.


Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 540.

questions.text: Upper lid coloboma most likely complication ?
questions.solution:
Exposure keratitis will be seen in the given condition as the patient will not be able to close eyelids.
Because the eyelid is inadequate, the cornea is constantly exposed to the environment, which can lead to exposure keratitis and subsequent bacterial infections.



Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th edition, Page no 59, 60.

questions.text: A man who injured his eye while using a hammer and chisel to try to break a stubborn stone was sent to the hospital. Which of the following investigations would be harmful?
questions.solution:
When a patient has metallic foreign bodies or implants in their body, MRI is not advised.
  • Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan is contraindicated in cases of magnetic or magnetizable foreign bodies, but is very useful in detecting a wooden foreign body and vascular changes.
  • Computerized axial tomography (CAT) scan: The thinnest slices are used to localize a small foreign body with great accuracy. The extent of bony, soft tissue and intracranial injuries can also be assessed.
  • Ultrasonography allows the detection of most foreign bodies, as well as associated intraocular conditions such as retinal detachment, suprachoroidal haemorrhage and a perforating injury of the eye.

Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 504.

questions.text: A boy with long fingers and a subluxation of the lens has a slender build and lacks cystathionine synthase. Which amino acid needs to be added?
questions.solution:
Long fingers with Ectopia lentis suggests Homocystinuria in this case.
  • Vitamin B6 and cysteine supplements are used to treat it.
  • Classic homocystinuria, the most common form, results from reduced activity of cystathionine β-synthase, that condenses homocysteine with serine to form cystathionine. Cystathionine undergoes trans-sulfuration with the help of Cystathionase to convert into alpha-keto butyrate and cysteine. Thus in the absence of Cystathionine beta-synthase, cysteine is not formed.
  • Cysteine is involved in the metabolism of homocysteine, it is important to supplement with cysteine in order to reduce the amount of homocysteine in the body and lower the risk of medical complications.
  • Patients are advised protein and methionine restricted diet.


Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3271, 3272.

questions.text:
A woman complains of nasal blockage and visits the ENT OPD.
Turbinate and septum covered by o/e greenish-black crust in nasal cavity.
She also exhibited kind anosmia. What additional indication can you look for in this situation?
questions.solution:
Merciful anosmia is the classical finding of atrophic rhinitis.
Roomy nasal cavity is also a feature of the same.
Atrophic rhinitis, also known as chronic atrophic rhinitis, is an ongoing inflammation of the nose that is characterised by the atrophy of the nasal mucosa, which includes the glands, turbinate bones, and nerve components that feed the nose. Primary and secondary chronic atrophic rhinitis are both possible. Females are most frequently affected by it. Patients from lower socioeconomic categories have reported it.
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 173

questions.text:
30y old with history of repeated middle ear infections in the past now developed Fever with Altered sensorium since three days. CT scan was taken which is shown below
The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Temporal lobe abscess.

  • The given axial CECT brain section shows presence of ring enhancing lesion in left temporal lobe. The given radiographic finding along with history of chronic ear infection points towards diagnosis of temporal lobe abscess. 
  • The CT brain scan reveals a tumour that resembles a ring and is indicative of a temporal abscess.
  • CSOM is the most typical cause of brain abscess. The infection causes a temporal lobe abscess when it enters the ear and travels to the tegmen tympani. It can also cause a posterior fossa abscess by entering through a sinodural abscess.



Reference: Scott-Brown's Otorhinolaryngology and Head and Neck Surgery Volume 2: Paediatrics, The Ear, and Skull Base Surgery, 8th edition, Page no 1012.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with epistaxis arrives. Attempts at conservative management to control the bleeding were unsuccessful. Which step will come next?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation must be done next.

In situations where conservative therapy is ineffective, endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation is performed.
In cases where this does not help, maxillary artery and ECA ligation are performed in that order.
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 201

questions.text: A thyroidectomy patient was being extubated. The anesthesiologist discovered that the patient starts to experience recurring cyanotic spells when the tube is removed. Which of the subsequent might be the reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) B/L RLN palsy
 
  • Recurring cyanotic spells after extubation suggest bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) palsy.
  • RLN palsy can occur as a complication of thyroidectomy.
  • It leads to vocal cord dysfunction and can result in airway compromise.
  • Immediate intervention may be required to secure the airway and ensure adequate oxygenation.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 864.

questions.text: In which of the following condition is the drug in the picture used topically?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Subglottic stenosis

EXPLANATIONS:-
  • Subglottic stenosis is defined as the narrowing of the upper airway, which lies between the vocal folds and the lower border of the cricoid cartilage.  
  • CAUSES: -
    • Congenital
    • Trauma
    • Infection   
  • MANAGEMENT: - Mitomycin is the drug of choice in post Subglottic Stenosis operation to prevent regrowth of fibroblasts and prevents restenosis.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 927.

choices.text: Take to OT, remove the clot and re-ligation

questions.text:
The ward contained a child who had undergone a tonsillectomy. In the ward, he began to have oral bleed and clots were seen
Which of the following has to be carried out?
questions.solution:
When the child is on the ward and the bleeding is happening within 24 hours of surgery, this is a case of reactionary haemorrhage. Reactonary Hemorrhage occurs due to splippage of sutures. 
For initial bleeding, cautery and pressure packing are used. Religation is the primary therapeutic method for reactive and secondary bleeding.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 489

questions.text:
The Wharton's duct was ligated during a patient's submandibular gland excision procedure.
Which of the following nerves has the highest chance of suffering damage?
questions.solution:
Submandibular glands are present below the mandible on both sides. Most common nerve injured:
Lingual nerve > Hypoglossal nerve


 

Reference:Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 27th Edition Page no.783

questions.text: A patient with skull base trauma was admitted. The designated structure was being examined by the specialist. Which of the next nerves is being examined?
questions.solution:
The area marked in the given image is palate, which is supplied by the the glossopharyngeal nerve.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464.e21,702.e1

questions.text: Which vaccine must be administered to a 10-year-old school student as part of the school health programme?
questions.solution:
TT, Td should be administered.
 
  • Older children require the Tdap vaccination, which contains a full dose of tetanus but a lesser dosage of diphtheria and pertussis since protection to tetanus declines with age.
  • Preteen children should have a Tdap vaccination as part of their routine annual checkups until they are 18 years old.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 136.

questions.text: Since she was three months old, a girl kid has experienced recurrent yeast and respiratory viral infections. Which vaccine is now contraindicated when immune status tests are taken into account?
questions.solution:

questions.text: In Kerala, after flood, people were complaining of fever. Doxycycline prophylactically distributed, along with it which insecticide is preferred?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: ZINC PHOSPHIDE
 
  • In Kerala, people experiencing fever after food consumption are suspected to have ingested contaminated food, possibly contaminated with rodent droppings.
  • To prevent the spread of foodborne diseases, prophylactic distribution of doxycycline, an antibiotic, is given to potentially affected individuals.
  • In addition to the antibiotic, Zinc phosphide is the preferred insecticide used for controlling rodent populations in the affected area.
  • Zinc phosphide is a rodenticide used to kill animals like mice and rats. It is a highly toxic compound and can produce toxicity by oral ingestion, inhalation, and through damaged skin.
Acute or single-dose rodenticides are classified according to the precautions that need to be taken before their use:

questions.text:
Hernia surgery is currently taking place in the operating room. Near the inferior epigastric artery, the sac is located medially.
What exactly is a hernia and how is it treated?
questions.solution:
• Surgery of Choice for direct inguinal hernia is Lichtenstein tension free mesh hernioplasty.
  • It has the least recurrence rate.
  • A Lichtenstein repair of a direct hernia is a tension-free mesh repair.
  • The direct hernia is isolated from the cord structures, and then invaginated back into the abdominal cavity. The defect in the wall is then closed by suture, after which the mesh is fixed to bridge the defect.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1068.

questions.text: A patient appears with dilated veins while having no complaints. What CEAP staging corresponds to the picture below?
questions.solution:
CEAP classification:
  • C0 - No visible or palpable varicose veins
  • C1 - Telangectasia Thread veins / Spider veins / Broken veins
  • C2A - Varicose veins without any symptoms (Asymptomatic)
  • C2S - Varicose veins with symptoms
  • C3 - Swollen ankle (oedema) due to varicose veins
  • C4A - Eczema
  • C4B- Atrophe blanche or lipodermatosclerosis
  • C4C- Corona phlebactesia 
  • C5 - Healed venous leg ulcer
  • C6 - Venous leg ulcer
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1030.

questions.text:
After 3 months, the patient's upper limbs were still swollen from the mastectomy for cancer breast.
What exactly is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Upper limb lymphedema
 
  • In this case upper limb lymphedema develops after 3 months post mastectomy.
  • Upper limb lymphangiosarcoma develops in a chronically edematous limb which usually takes around 10 years to develop. It is known as stewart-treves syndrome.
  • Lymphedema-associated angiosarcoma (Stewart-Treves) develops on an extremity ipsilateral to an axillary lymphadenectomy. It appears on the upper, medial arm as a violaceous plaque in an individual with nonpitting edema and has a poor survival.
  • Radiation-induced angiosarcoma occurs 4 to 25 years after radiation therapy for benign and malignant conditions.

Fig: Stewart‐Treves Syndrome Involving Chronic Lymphedema after Mastectomy of Breast Cancer

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 535.

questions.text: A 56 year old female who underwent open hysterectomy two years back presented with abdominal pain, vomiting and obstipation. Increased bowel sounds could be heard on auscultation. On erect abdominal Xray, air in the biliary tree along with dilated bowel loops were visible. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. Gallstone ileus

Small bowel obstruction, a gallstone outside the gallbladder, and air in the bile ducts make up the Rigler's triad.
 
  • An rare reason for a mechanical small intestinal obstruction is gallstone ileus.
  • A gallstone can get impacted at the ileocecal valve by passing via a fistula between the small intestine and gallbladder, which is an uncommon consequence of chronic cholecystitis.
  • The buildup of gas in the biliary tree is referred to as pneumobilia or aerobilia.
  • It's critical to distinguish between pneumobilia and the other branching hepatic gas type, portal venous gas.
  • There are numerous causes of pneumobilia, and the clinical setting is frequently crucial for separating them.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1247.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man who had a 2x3 cm prostate lesion presented to the OPD. PSA is 8. Gleason rating is six. What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
• Gleason sums for well-differentiated cancers range from 2-4, moderately differentiated tumors from 5-6, and poorly differentiated tumors from 8-10.
  • The initial T stage, Gleason score, and baseline PSA are used in combination to more accurately predict risk and direct treatment choices.
  • Yet, given that the patient is 80 years old, comorbidities are a possibility here. As a result, we will continue to actively monitor the patient.
 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1534.

questions.text: Which surgery is depicted in the picture?

It is a straightforward operation that narrows the Anus using a suture or prosthetic.

Urethrography utilising water soluble contrast is used to make the diagnosis which is done first followed by
Suprapubic catheter placement is the initial treatment (SPC) if injury present.

questions.text: What metabolic abnormality is seen in a newborn with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Hypochloremic Hyponatremic Metabolic Alkalosis.
 
  • The hypertrophic pyloric muscle causes gastric outlet obstruction which leads to recurrent vomiting. Hydrochloric acid(HCl) of stomach is vomited out, body becomes deficient in H+ ions resulting in Metabolic Alkalosis
  • Cl- ions are also lost leading to hypochloremia
  • To compensate for the metabolic alkalosis, kidney eliminates sodium bicarbonate ions in urine, which leads to decrease Na+ in the body stimulating RAAS.
  • Aldosterone acts on collecting duct and stimulates reabsorption of Na+ and in return secretion of K+ and H+ resulting in hypokalemia and paradoxical aciduria.
CHPS presents as projectile non-bilious vomiting 2-3 weeks after birth after feeding. Visible peristalsis from left to right followed by a lump in the epigastrium.

Investigation of choice for CHPS – USG

Diagnostic criteria
  1. Thickness >4mm
  2. Length of pylorus >16mm


Management: Ramstedts pyloromyotomy

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 274

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man with severe stomach pain and distension arrives at the emergency room.
In the epigastric region, there is a fluid-filled lesion. Which of the following investigation may not be useful?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: GGT
 
  • GGT (gamma-glutamyl transferase) is an enzyme primarily associated with liver function and bile duct pathology.
  • It is not typically used as an investigation for evaluating a fluid-filled lesion in the epigastric region, probably a pancreatic cyst.
  • Other investigations, such as imaging studies (ultrasound, CT scan), may be more appropriate to determine the cause of the symptoms.
  • GGT levels may be elevated in liver diseases, but it is not specific to this particular clinical presentation.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1194.

questions.text: A patient with an abdominal blunt injury shows up with flank ecchymoses. His health is stable. Which of the following investigations is appropriate for identifying where the bleeding is occurring?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: CECT Abdomen
 
  • Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) of the abdomen is the investigation of choice for evaluating abdominal injuries and identifying the source of bleeding.
  • CECT can provide detailed images of the abdominal organs, blood vessels, and surrounding structures, helping to identify any active bleeding or organ damage.
  • It allows for accurate diagnosis and helps guide further management decisions, such as the need for surgical intervention or conservative management.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1478.

questions.text: A patient has been exhibiting signs/symptoms of a gastric outlet obstruction. He has several liver mets in the right lobe of his liver, as well as a tumour that has invaded his stomach, pancreas, and duodenum. What is the best course of action for him?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Palliative gastro jejunostomy is often used to bypass a gastric outlet obstruction and improve symptoms, especially when the obstruction is caused by a locally advanced malignancy.
It would offer symptomatic relief for the patient, helping with the obstruction and improving their ability to eat and digest food
About 15% of the time, the duodenum is blocked.
If this happens early in the disease's progression, a gastrojejunostomy is performed as a surgical bypass.
Rest of the procedures are radical given the advanced stage of the disease, a palliative procedure would be the best option.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1161.

questions.text:
Two years after undergoing a cholecystectomy, the patient was readmitted to the hospital with bile duct stones.
What is the name of these stones?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Primary stone
 
  • Stones that form in the Bile Duct can cause primary choledocholithiasis, or they can move from the gallbladder to the Bile Duct, causing secondary choledocholithiasis.
  • Primary choledocholithiasis was defined as those that appeared two years after cholecystectomy, whereas residual or secondary choledocholithiasis was defined as those that appeared in the first two years following cholecystectomy.

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 642.

questions.text: Lumbar puncture is being performed by you. Which structure will you encounter last?
questions.solution:
Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous and interspinous ligaments, ligamentum flavum, epidural space containing the internal spinal venous plexus, dura, arachnoid, and lastly the subarachnoid space are all punctured by the lumbar puncture needle in that order.



Reference: Jane LA, Wray AA. Lumbar Puncture. [Updated 2023 Jul 24]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557553/

questions.text:
During surgery, the patient's anaesthetic caused significant hyperthermia and muscle rigidity.
What other agent from the list below would have contributed to this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Succinylcholine

The given clinical vignette describes the condition called Malignant Hyperthermia which is a very common side effect following the use of succinylcholine.
  • Succinylcholine is a Nicotinic Receptor antagonist which produces sustained muscle depolarisation and prevents muscle contraction.
  • It stimulates the motor endplate to initiate muscle depolarization.
  • In Malignant Hyperthermia patients succinylcholine results in hyperthermia and generalized muscle rigidity.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 379.

questions.text: A 30 year old man had surgery while being intubated. The most effective way to verify the location of the endotracheal tube is:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. ETCO2

  • The most important and objective indicator of tracheal intubation, however, is the presence of a normal capnogram (carbon dioxide [CO2] waveform) for the presence of at least three breaths. Severe bronchospasm, equipment malfunction, cardiac arrest, or hemodynamic collapse may prevent the appearance of a capnogram tracing despite proper ETT placement. If doubt remains, then flexible bronchoscopy, although not routinely used, is very reliable at confirming ETT placement.
  • In patients with adequate tissue perfusion, assess and confirm the location of the endotracheal tube using an end-tidal carbon dioxide detector (such as continuous waveform capnography, colorimetric capnography, or non-waveform capnography)

Signs of correct endotracheal intubation:
  1. Detection of ETCO2 by Capnography (Surest confirmation)
  2. Bilaterally auscultated breath sounds
  3. Symmetric chest rise
  4. Absence of epigastric breath sound
  5. Visible mist in the ET tube
  6. Large exhaled Tidal volume
  7. Good compliance of reservoir bag during manual ventilation


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1308, 1309, 1392-1398.

questions.text: The illustration for airway management shown below contains:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Chin lift.
 
  • The illustration shows the technique of Head tilt and chin lift, which is a maneuver used to open the airway and improve ventilation.
  • During airway management, lifting the chin upwards helps to extend the neck, move the tongue away from the posterior pharyngeal wall, and open the oropharynx.
  • The chin lift is a simple and effective method to relieve airway obstruction in patients who do not have a suspected cervical spine injury




Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anesthesiology, 5th edition, Page no 1232, 1235.
Austin, Naola et al. “Airway management in cervical spine injury.” International journal of critical illness and injury science vol. 4,1 (2014): 50-6. doi:10.4103/2229-5151.128013

questions.text: A young male patient received 0.25% Bupivacaine regional anaesthetic. The patient lost consciousness, and it was impossible to monitor their pulse. The ideal course of action would have been:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) CPCR with 20% intralipid
 
  • Due to the patient's unresponsiveness and unrecordable pulse, CPCR will be initiated, and Intralipid 20% should be administered as an antidote.
  • Most local anesthetics produce similar signs and symptoms, but the ratio of neurotoxicity to cardiotoxicity may differ, with bupivacaine being the most cardiotoxic.
  • The incidence of toxicity is rare: 1 to 1000 to 1 to 10000. Be concerned for local anesthetic toxicity (LAST) with abnormal cardiovascular or neurological signs and symptoms.

* [Extra Edge]: Bupivacaine Toxicity
 
  1. At therapeutic levels, local anesthetics block voltage-gated Na-channels at the alpha subunit inside the channel, preventing Na+ influx, preventing depolarization, and action potential generation. They affect cardiac Na+-channels and neurons in the brain at toxic levels, blocking K+, Ca2+, and NMDA receptors. 
  2. It lowers the seizure threshold and increases cerebral blood flow, leading to more local anesthetic into the brain.
  3. CNS toxicity includes - perioral tingling, tinnitus, blurry vision, and tongue paresthesia.
  4. Terminal Cardiac toxicity includes - vasodilation, severe hypotension, dysrhythmias, conduction blocks, and asystole.
  5. Treatment of bupivacaine toxicity has long been challenging due to its profound neurologic and cardiac toxicity. Previously, treatment had been supportive, with standard cardiopulmonary resuscitation, airway management, and seizure control with quick-acting GABA agonists such as midazolam. 
  6. For a patient of less than 70 kg, bolus 1.5 mL/kg lipid emulsion 20% rapidly over 2 to 3 minutes, followed by an infusion of 0.25 mL/kg/min for ideal body weight to an upper limit of 12 mL/kg.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 393.

Online Reference: Shafiei FT, McAllister RK, Lopez J. Bupivacaine. [Updated 2023 Aug 17]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK532883/

questions.text: The following is the X ray of a patient who presented with abdominal pain and multiple episodes of vomiting. The abdominal X ray is given below. These loops correspond to which part of the intestines?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Jejunum.
 
  • This abdominal radiograph shows dilated bowel loops located centrally in the abdomen with multiple complete transverse lines with-Volvulae conniventes-s/o small bowel loops. 
  • Large bowel loops are always peripheral in location and show incomplete transverse wall folds- haustrations.
  • Among small bowel loops, jejunal loops are located in the upper abdomen- as in this image- with prominent mucosal folds. 
  • Ileal loops are located in the lower central abdomen and do not show prominent wall folds. 
Hence these loops are jejunal loops. 


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 597-599, 672.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1288.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with dull agonising back discomfort and sterile pyuria. A radiograph is displayed. What cause is most likely?
questions.solution:
• Often seen on plain radiography, a putty kidney is a pattern of renal calcification linked to renal TB.
  • The calcification, which represents calcified caseous tissue, is typically very uniform and ground glass-like.
  • A lobar pattern of calcification, in which dense calcific rims outline the margin of deformed renal lobes, must be distinguished from putty calcification.
  • When it comes to autonephrectomy, lobar calcification is an end-stage look.
  • A patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, with the given x-ray showing diffuse alveolar calcification in the right renal region point towards a diagnosis of a putty kidney. 
  • The putty kidney is a characteristic finding of genitourinary tuberculosis (TB), specifically renal TB. The given image shows a homogenous and ground-glass-like calcification of the kidney appearing like putty.
  • It is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream and is thus always a secondary TB. There is either reinfection or reactivation of old TB. 
  • Genitourinary TB is a cause of sterile pyuria.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with a tuberculin test, or at least 3 consecutive early-morning specimens of urine are examined for acid-fast bacilli. They are stained with a Ziehl-Neelsen stain and subsequently cultured. 
  • CT is the most sensitive modality and is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications.
CT urography is done to assess the various stages of renal TB and its manifestations, which are as follows: 

Early:
• Papillary necrosis
Progressive:
• Multifocal strictures
• Generalized or focal hydronephrosis
• Mural thickening and enhancement
• Poorly enhancing renal parenchyma
End-stage:
• Progressive hydronephrosis
• Amorphous dystrophic calcification that involves the entire kidney - putty kidney 

 
  • Treatment involves short-course therapy with antitubercular drugs like pyrazinamide, isoniazid, and rifampicin. Partial nephrectomy, nephrectomy, or reconstructive surgery is often done. 



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1045, 1046.
Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 748.

2. Penetrating injury in abdomen

questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy who had been having trouble swallowing for a few hours was taken to the emergency room by his mother.
He was seen playing unattended. An X-ray was obtained. Find the foreign body's location.
questions.solution:
The oesophagus may contain a spherical metallic foreign body that is located in the midline immediately above the aortic knob. However, the coin cannot fit inside the trachea because its diameter exceeds that of the trachea, and on the lateral view, the trachea appears anterior to the coin.

Trick: -
In oesophagus- in AP view coin diameter is seen
In trachea- in AP view lateral surface of coin is seen

questions.text:
A patient who had experienced an RTA was sent to casualty. His pulse rate was weak, coming in around 110 bpm.
On the left side of the thorax, there is decreased air entry. The systolic blood pressure is 70. Upon inspection, bruises and left hypochondrium ecchymosis are present. What steps must be taken next?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: E FAST
 
  • The clinical presentation, including weak pulse rate, decreased air entry on the left side of the thorax, and hypotension, suggests the possibility of a significant intra-abdominal injury, such as splenic or hepatic injury.
  • This patient has bruises over the left hypochondrium, indicating a possible splenic injury.
  • Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) is a bedside ultrasound examination that can quickly assess for free fluid in the abdomen, indicating internal bleeding.
  • It is a rapid and non-invasive way to evaluate trauma patients and guide further management decisions, such as the need for immediate surgical intervention.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 378.

questions.text: A 63-year-old hypertensive patient who was also experiencing diaphoresis presented. He exhibits uneven pulses in both arms upon inspection. ECG showed non-specific ST-T changes. Which of the following imaging studies is most helpful in this situation?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Aortic Dissection.
The clinical presentation and ECG revealing nonspecific ST-T changes strongly suggest aortic dissection. Given the patient’s hemodynamic instability, the next best investigation is a transesophageal echocardiogram.

Aortic Dissection:

Aortic dissection occurs when a tear or flap develops in the intima of the aorta, allowing blood to track into the aortic tissues and split the medial layer.

Predisposing Factors:
- Age
- Hypertension
- Marfan syndrome
- Pregnancy
- Other connective tissue disorders (e.g., Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, giant cell arteritis, systemic lupus erythematosus)
- Coarctation of the aorta
- Turner or Noonan syndromes
- Iatrogenic factors (e.g., aortic cannulation)

Clinical Features:
  • The hallmark presentation of aortic dissection is severe tearing pain between the shoulder blades, often accompanied by diaphoresis. Additional symptoms may include syncope, weakness, and dyspnea.
  • Physical examination may reveal hypertension or hypotension, loss of pulses, signs of aortic regurgitation, pulmonary edema, or neurological deficits. Unequal pulses or blood pressure in the limbs may indicate alterations in blood flow between the true and false lumens.
 
  • An endoscopic transducer is inserted into the esophagus during a typical transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE), a type of ultrasonography that provides a generally better view of the major vessels and posterior cardiac structures than the transthoracic method (TTE).
  • To evaluate cardiac and aortic structures, TOE is most frequently utilised in the fields of anesthesiology, cardiology, and critical care.
 
  • IOC in hemodynamically unstable patient: TEE
  • IOC in hemodynamically stable patient: CT angiography



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2104, 2105.

questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus

 
  • Prostaglandins (PGE1) is responsible for keeping the ductus arteriosus patent.
  • Indomethacin inhibits prostaglandin production.
