questions.text: The fetal circulation is different from adult circulation. It recieves oxygenated blood from palcenta via X and deoxygenated blood goes back through:
questions.solution:
In fetal circulation, oxygenated blood is received from the placenta via the umbilical vein (option 2). Deoxygenated blood is returned to the placenta through the umbilical arteries (option 1).

Explanation:

  • Umbilical vein: Carries oxygen-rich blood from the placenta to the fetus.

  • Umbilical arteries: Carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus back to the placenta for oxygenation.

  • Ductus venosus: Bypasses the liver, allowing oxygenated blood to reach the heart more efficiently.

  • Ductus arteriosus: Connects the pulmonary artery to the aorta, bypassing the lungs since they are not yet functional.

questions.text:
A 24 year old Primigravida woman with a 3-year history of infertility shows up with amenorrhea lasting six weeks.
She has sporadic PV and slight stomach pain. Her UPT is marginally optimistic. She is hemodynamically stable upon assessment.
There is a left-sided adnexal lesion measuring 3 × 2.5 cm. B HCG : 2800 A left-sided tubal gestational sac is visible on ultrasound, but there is no heart activity. Which is the most effective management strategy?
questions.solution:
• The size of G sac is less than 3.5 cm and there is no cardiac activity.
  • Hence , the patient is a candidate for medical management of ectopic.
  • Methotrexate IM injection is an appropriate and effective treatment option, particularly when the ectopic pregnancy is detected early, the patient is stable, and there are no contraindications to the drug.
  • Salpingectomy (removal of the fallopian tube) is usually reserved for more advanced cases or when the tube is ruptured or severely damaged.
  • Milking the tube is not recommended, as it can lead to increased risk of tubal damage and recurrence.
  • Expectant management is not suitable here due to the persistent ectopic pregnancy with significant β-hCG levels and visible ectopic gestation.

questions.text: What is the name of the examination indicated below in a female who presented with recurrent miscarriage?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Hysterosalpingography.
 
  • Hysterosalpingography is a fluoroscopic procedure wherein a cannula (Leech Wilkinson cannula) in inserted in the cervix and iodinated contrast material is injected through it.  
  • The contrast outlines the uterine cavity, bilateral fallopian tubes and shows free spill into the peritoneal cavity.
  • It is primarily done for evaluation of infertility to look for causes such as 
    • Tubal patency/tubal pathology such as cornual block, hydrosalpinx. 
    • Mullerian duct anomalies
    • Uterine adhesions 
  • The best time to perform hysterosalpingography is between day 6 and day 10 of menstrual cycle.  

A radiologic method called hysterosalpingography, also called uterosalpingography, examines the fallopian tubes' size, shape, and patency in addition to the uterine cavity's contour. This denotes a unique x-ray that uses dye to examine the Fallopian tubes and womb.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old lady is being evaluated for multiple, subsequent miscarriages. An ultrasound suggests a mullerian abnormality.

questions.solution:
There is already suspicion of Mullerian anomaly on ultrasound.
So a diagnostic laproscopy and hysteroscopy can be done which will give view of both inside and outside contour of the uterus which can confirm the type of Mullerian anomaly.

Mullerian abnormalities:
Type 1 :- MRHK or Mullerian agenesis 
Type 2 :- Unicornuate uterus -1 sided mullerian duct develops - never leads to transverse lie (PYQ)
Type 3 :- Didelphic uterus - lack of fusion of both the mullerian ducts 
Type 4:- Bicornuate uterus - incomplete fusion 
-angle b/w 2 horns more than 75 degrees 
Type 5:- Septate uterus - septa which forms after fusion fails to resolve 
- mc type 
- mc type causing infertility 
-angle less than 75 degress 
- Treatment - metroplasty ,hysteroscopic septal resection(PYQ)
Type 6 :- Arcuate uterus - flat topped 
- no anatomical abnormality 
Type 7:- DES related anomalies - hypoplastic uterus ,T shaped uterus

Diagnosis :- 
1. Hysterosalpingography 
2. IOC = 3D USG 
3. Gold Standard - MRI 
4. BEST - Laparoscopy + Hysteroscopy(PYQ)

questions.text:
Reema Devi, a 28-year-old newlywed, walks into your sub centre looking for contraceptive counselling.
Her oral contraceptive pill regimen has begun. She shows up two weeks later with a history of skipping four tablets on various days during the first two weeks of her cycle. What advice will you give her?
questions.solution:
If two or more consecutive hormonal pills have been missed: (≥48 hours since a pill should have been taken)
 
  • Take the most recent missed pill as soon as possible (any other missed pills should be discarded).
  • Continue taking the remaining pills at the usual time (even if it means taking two pills on the same day).
  • Use back-up contraception (e.g., condoms) or avoid sexual intercourse until hormonal pills have been taken for 7 consecutive days.
  • Emergency contraception may also be considered at other times as appropriate.

questions.text: A P0A3 arrives and has had three abortions in the past. First at 8 weeks, second at 11 weeks, and third at 24 weeks, all having a history of preeclampsia with early onset. Which of the following explains her abortions the most likely?
questions.solution:
The patient has history of recurrent pregnancy loss with h/o pre Eclampsia which is seen in Anti phospholipid antibodies syndrome.
Modified Sapro criteria is used for its diagnosis
Clinical criteria 
1. Vascular thrombosis: \( \geq 1\) arterial, venous, or small vessel thrombosis 
2. Pregnancy morbidity 
a. \( \geq 1\) fetal death (at or beyond the 10th week of gestation)
b. \( \geq 1\) premature birth before the 34th week of gestation because of eclampsia, severe preeclampsia, or placental insufficiency 
c. \( \geq 3\) consecutive (pre) embryonic losses (before the 10th week of gestation)  
Laboratory criteria 
1. Lupus  anticoagulant positivity on \( \geq 2\) occasions at least 12 weeks  apart. 
2. Anticardiolipin antibody (IgG and/ or IgM) in medium or high titer (i.e., >40, or above the 99th percentile), on two or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart 
3. Anti-\(\beta2\)-glycoprotein-I antibody (IgG and/or IgM) in medium or higher titer (i.e., above the 99th percentile)on two or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart.

Definite APS is present if at least one of the clinical certeria and one of the laboratory criteria are met.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old lady complains of being tired and lethargic when she visits the medicine office. She recalls having a 3.5 kg baby delivered five years prior, and the numerous blood transfusions that followed. After giving birth, she never started her period again, and she also experienced lactation problems.
Which diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Sheehan syndrome.
  • The most likely diagnosis in this case is Sheehan syndrome, also known as postpartum pituitary necrosis.
  • Sheehan syndrome is characterized by pituitary gland damage due to severe postpartum hemorrhage, leading to hormonal imbalances and symptoms such as fatigue, amenorrhea, and lactation problems.
  • The most common hormone deficiency in Sheehan syndrome is hypothyroidism (thyroid gland does not produce enough thyroid hormone).
  • The patient's symptoms of tiredness, lethargy, and lack of menstruation are consistent with hypothyroidism. The fact that she had a large baby and needed multiple blood transfusions during childbirth suggests that she may have had Sheehan syndrome.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2890.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought by her mother to the OPD. She worries about being shorter than her peers. Upon examination, the patient has webbed neck, shield-like chest, and ptosis on the right side. What would you expect to discover after evaluation?
questions.solution:
Girls and women are affected by the hereditary condition known as Turner syndrome.
  • Turner syndrome is brought on by an entirely or partially absent X chromosome.
  • Short stature, irregular periods, and lack of breast development are among the signs of Turner syndrome.
  • The majority of patients, who are often female, have streak ovaries, which can cause primary amenorrhea or premature ovarian failure. Usually, the ovaries initially develop correctly, but the egg cells die too soon, and the majority of the ovarian tissue deteriorates before delivery.
  • The majority of girls need hormone therapy to reach menarche and develop secondary sexual characteristics.
  • Although the ovaries will have streaks, the uterus, fallopian tubes, and vagina will all develop normally.

Coarctation of the aorta in older children presents as:
  • Intermittent claudication pain
  • Feeble femoral pulse
  • Radiofemoral delay
  • Upper limb Hypertension due to descending aorta obstruction
  • Inferior rib notching due to development and dilation of collaterals.
  • Esophageal compression appearing as Reverse 3 sign.



 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 428,429

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is diagnosed with myoclonus jerk, which affects his academic performance.
There is a history of fever and rash at the age of one year. The features mentioned above point to:
questions.solution:
• History of fever and rash at one year of age (probably measles) & current presentation at 10 year of age with myoclonic jerks indicate chronic complication seen in measles called Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE).
  • It is a progressive neurological disorder of children and young adults that affects the central nervous system (CNS).
  • It is a slow, but persistent, viral infection caused by  measles virus.
  • More common in regions with low vaccination rates.
  • Stages of SSPE- 
Stage 1: Gradual onset of behavioral changes, personality changes, memory loss, school difficulties, and irritability.

Stage 2: Development of myoclonus (involuntary jerking movements), seizures, and progressive intellectual decline.

Stage 3: Further neurological deterioration with worsening myoclonus, spasticity, and severe dementia.

Stage 4: End-stage disease characterized by a vegetative state, decerebrate rigidity, and eventually death.
Diagnosis- 
  • EEG: Periodic, high-voltage discharges (burst-suppression pattern).
  • CSF analysis: Elevated measles antibodies (oligoclonal bands or high titers of anti-measles IgG).
  • MRI: Brain shows signs of inflammation and demyelination.
  • Measles antibody titers: Significantly elevated in both the blood and cerebrospinal fluid.


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 209,210

questions.text: Deformed bones were present in a 4-year-old kid who also has a history of recurrent infections and belongs to a low SE status. Calcium levels were normal, but his PTH levels were high. There was low phosphate. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A child with a history of recurring infections/ poor SE status with normal Ca,low phosphate and high PTH suggests a nutritional deficiency of vitamin D (option 4) leading to rickets and hence, the deformed bones. 
In nutritional rickets, low Vit D3 leads to decreased Ca2+/PO4- absorption and leads to low phosphate(due to decreased phosphate absorption) and lowered Calcium levels initially which in turn stimulates the release of PTH and leads to high PTH (High PTH can make Ca2+ levels normal for a while). 

Other options
  • Vit D-dependent rickets will have similar biochemical parameters but also a history of resistance to Vit D supplementation. 
  • X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets will have low Phosphate but normal PTH. It will also have history of oligodontia/dental abscess which is not given in the question stem. 

The question stem with recurrent infection and low SE status points towards Nutritional deficiency rather than Vitamin D dependent Rickets/X linked Hypophosphatemic rickets



 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 112-114

choices.text: Blood culture and CSF culture from shunt tap

questions.text:
Due to shunt malfunction, a 4-year-old child with hydrocephalus who has ventricular shunt had it changed.
The youngster now complains of irritation and lack of appetite that has lasted for three days with no other symptoms; the rectal temperature was 38.7 C. What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Blood culture and CSF culture from shunt tap
  • The child is complaining of irritation and lack of appetite, a recent history of changing shunt along with these symptoms is suggestive of shunt associated meningitis.
  • The next best step in this case will be taking blood culture and CSF sampling from shunt tap.
  • Shunt aspiration is preferable to a lumbar puncture as it allows better detection of microbes and avoids the need of a separate procedure reducing the risk of contamination.

Option 1 – Blood culture should be done on all cases of suspected meningitis but the diagnosis of meningitis is confirmed by CSF analysis obtained from shunt tap.

Option 3 – IV antibiotics are the mainstay of treatment but should be started after taking blood and CSF samples, this is not the best next step.

Option 4 – shunt patent studies are performed to determine whether shunt revision surgery is needed in the malfunctioned VP shunt. It is done using radionucleotide dyes.



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 561-563,578

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl who had arthritis, hematuria, and palpable purpura abdominal pain appeared. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Henoch Schonlein Purpura

The clinical scenario of arthritis, hematuria,  purpura and abdominal pain is suggestive of HSP.
  • Also known as IgA vasculitis as there is deposition of IgA in the small vessels of skin,joints, kidney and GI tract.
  • Type 3 hypersensitivity reaction
  • Occurs following a URTI by group A streptococcus
  • Clinical features :
  1. Palpable purpura in lower extremities and extensor surfaces
  2. Arthralgia and arthritis
  3. GI manifestations like abdominal pain, intususseption
  4. Renal manifestations like microscopic hematuria, PSGN
  • Management : symptomatic treatment by prednisolone, azathioprine, glucocorticoids.
     
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 628-630

questions.text:
A patient, 45 years old, complains of chest trouble. An angiogram was performed, and the results showed blocked left circumflex artery. After the stenting, the patient was started on 75 mg of aspirin, 20 mg of atorvastatin, and 50 mg of metoprolol.
Which of the following statements about the patient's future care is true?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Add P2Y12 Inhibitor.
 
  • After the stenting, the patient was started on the following medications:
    • 75 mg of aspirin (standard antiplatelet therapy).
    • 20 mg of atorvastatin (statin to lower cholesterol).
    • 50 mg of metoprolol (beta-blocker to manage blood pressure and heart rate).
 
  • The patient's future care requires the addition of a P2Y12 inhibitor to complete the dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) after coronary stenting.
  • The most common P2Y12 inhibitors used for MI are clopidogrel, prasugrel, and ticagrelor.
  • DAPT should be continued for at least 1 year post stenting to prevent stent thrombosis. After DAPT treatment for said duration, Aspirin should be continued lifelong.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2049, 2050.
Magnani, Giulia, and Marco Valgimigli. “Dual Antiplatelet Therapy After Drug-eluting Stent Implantation.” Interventional cardiology (London, England) vol. 11,1 (2016): 51-53. doi:10.15420/icr.2015:17:2. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5808681/

questions.text:
A patient has had a fever, nocturnal cough, shortness of breath, and wheezing for four weeks.
Absolute eosinophil count is greater than 5000. Miliary Pattern is shown on a chest X-ray. What medical diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Tropical Pulmonary Eosinophilia.
 
  • TPE is a hypersensitivity reaction to filarial parasites, Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi, transmitted through mosquito bites causing lymphatic filariasis.
  • Symptoms: Chronic cough, wheezing, and shortness of breath, often exacerbated at night (nocturnal).
  • Peripheral eosinophilia with an absolute eosinophil count > 5000 is a typical finding in TPE.


Other options :
 
  • Bronchial asthma can cause respiratory symptoms but lacks the miliary pattern and marked eosinophilia typical of TPE.
  • Miliary tuberculosis is a consideration but the marked eosinophilia and absence of other typical tuberculosis features make this option less likely.
  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis can cause eosinophilia but is characterized by inflammation due to allergen exposure and lacks the miliary pattern and marked eosinophilia typical of TPE.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1781.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman who had forearm claudication, temporary visual loss, and stomach pain presented. Her femoral pulses were likewise feeble. Retinal haemorrhages were also visible on fundus. What diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Takayasu arteritis is often referred to as Martorell syndrome, occlusive thromboaortopathy, and Pulseless disease.

Clinical traits: Limb numbness or discomfort, forearm claudications, lightheadedness or wooziness, difficulty focusing, eyesight issues.
Blood pressure is high, different BP in two limbs.

Vessel involvement and corresponding clinical manifestation in Takayasu arteritis: 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2811, 2813.

questions.text: A labourer went to the emergency room complaining of dizziness and extreme fatigue. When the doctor took his medical history, he revealed that he had been working in a hot environment; the temperature that day was 42°C. He had no sign of dehydration. All of the symptoms listed below could have been present, with the exception of :
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Sweating
 
  • The clinical scenario described in a patient who shows no signs of dehydration and has a body temperature of 42oC strongly indicates heatstroke, which is characterized by the absence of sweating.
  • Heatstroke, also known as thermic fever or heat hyperpyrexia, occurs due to a malfunction in the hypothalamus's heat regulation center, leading to inadequate cutaneous circulation and sweating. Contributing factors include high temperatures, elevated humidity, minor infections, advanced age, lack of acclimatization, and alcoholism.

Heatstroke can be classified into two types: 

1. Exertion-induced heatstroke: which affects individuals who experience prolonged exposure to or engage in strenuous physical activity in high temperatures, often without proper training. 

2. Sedentary heatstroke: which primarily impacts the elderly or those with health issues, whose cardiovascular systems struggle to manage the stress of a hot environment, resulting in a rise in body temperature.
 
  • Patients typically exhibit signs of shock, presenting with sudden collapse and loss of consciousness. Common vital sign abnormalities include tachypnea, tachycardia, hypotension, and a widened pulse pressure.
  • Additional specific symptoms may include rapid Kussmaul breathing, lack of sweating accompanied by dry, hot skin, delirium, coma, convulsions, rhabdomyolysis, and multi-organ failure.




Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology by KS Narayan Reddy, 33rd edition, Page no 319.

questions.text: Which of the following indicates a poor prognosis for multiple myeloma patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Serum ß2 Microglobulin

Beta 2 microglobulin, the light chain of the HL-A histocompatibility complex, is a low molecular weight protein that is present on the surface of all nucleated cells.
Patients with multiple myeloma who have higher serum beta 2 microglobulin levels have a worse prognosis.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 607.

choices.text: Propranolol is given initially to treat hypertension
Can present as Hypertension alone, sometime with abdominal pain and vomiting.

questions.text: Out of the following, which is a false statement regarding Pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Propranolol is not the preferred drug for HTN control in pheochromocytoma.
 
  • The most popular drug used to treat patients before pheochromocytoma excision is phenoxybenzamine, a non-selective alpha blocker.
  • Alpha blockers are given initially to manage hypertension followed by Beta blockers like propranolol which is given only after adequate alpha blockade has been achieved.
  • If beta blockers are given initially without alpha blockade, it will lead to unopposed alpha stimulation of catecholamines leading to hypertensive crisis.

Pheochromocytoma Overview

Definition:
Pheochromocytoma is a tumor that secretes catecholamines, arising from the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla. It can occur sporadically or as part of hereditary syndromes.

Hereditary Syndromes:
  • Hereditary pheochromocytomas are associated with conditions such as:
  • MEN 2 (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2)
  • Familial Paraganglioma Syndrome
  • Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) Syndrome
  • Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1)

Clinical Features:
The condition typically presents with a classic triad of:
  1. Intermittent headaches
  2. Palpitations
  3. Profuse sweating

Patients may also experience:
  • Hypertension
  • Anxiety
  • Panic attacks
  • Nausea
  • Abdominal pain
  • Weight loss
  • Weakness

Symptoms can be triggered by:
  • Surgery
  • Pregnancy
  • Changes in position
  • Exercise
  • Certain medications (e.g., metoclopramide, tricyclic antidepressants)

Investigations:
1. Biochemical Screening: Measurement of urinary and plasma catecholamines and metanephrines.
2. MRI: Preferred for tumor localization due to less risk of precipitating hypertensive episodes compared to CT scans.
3. Other Imaging: Techniques like MIBG scintigraphy, DOPA-PET, or FDG-PET scans can help identify the primary tumor and detect extra-adrenal tumors and metastases.

Treatment:
  • Surgical Resection: The definitive treatment for pheochromocytoma.
  • Preoperative Management: Hypertension is managed with alpha-blockers, followed by beta-blockers.
  • Postoperative Care: Lifelong yearly follow-ups are recommended to monitor for recurrence or complications.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2976.

questions.text: Patient with a history of recurring, 3-minute episodes of retrosternal chest discomfort that responded to sublingual nitrate. Presenting with chest pain in emergency. He has hypercholesterolemia, diabetes, and HTN. He is taking metformin, lovastatin, aspirin, and atenolol. ECG displays a Flat T wave and LVH. What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
The current clinical situation points to a diagnosis of Unstable angina.

Acute coronary syndrome is divided into two main groups: 

1. ST-segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI)
2. Non-ST-Elevation Acute Coronary Syndrome (NSTE-ACS)

NSTE-ACS is further categorized into:

- NSTEMI (where myocyte necrosis is present and cardiac troponins are elevated)
- Unstable Angina (where myocyte necrosis is absent and cardiac troponins are not elevated)

The diagnosis of NSTE-ACS relies on the following criteria:

- Severe chest discomfort accompanied by at least one of these three features:
  - Occurrence at rest or with minimal exertion, lasting more than 10 minutes
  - Recent onset
  - Crescendo pattern

Additionally, the ECG may show:
- ST segment depression
- T wave inversion
- Elevated cardiac troponins in the case of NSTEMI.

Management of NSTE-ACS:
 
  • To alleviate pain and discomfort, the initial treatment includes bed rest, nitrates, beta blockers, and inhaled oxygen (administered only if arterial oxygen saturation is below 90%).
  • Antithrombotic therapy involves both antiplatelet and anticoagulant medications:
- Dual Antiplatelet Therapy (DAPT): Aspirin (162-325 mg) plus one ADP receptor inhibitor (Ticagrelor, Clopidogrel, or Prasugrel).
- Anticoagulation: Options include Enoxaparin, unfractionated heparin, Fondaparinux, or Bivalirudin.
 
  • An early invasive strategy is recommended for stabilized patients at high risk for coronary events (based on TIMI, GRACE, or HEART scores). This includes diagnostic coronary angiography within 2-72 hours of presentation, followed by revascularization (either percutaneous coronary intervention or coronary artery bypass grafting).
 
  • Many LMWHs, including dalteparin, enoxaparin etc have been examined in unstable angina. Nadroparin decreased the risk of ischemic events in a small open study when compared to aspirin alone or a combination of aspirin and conventional heparin.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2047, 2051.

questions.text: A patient has been taking analgesics on a regular basis for the past two years despite her headache complaints.There is no prior history of photophobia, nausea, or vomiting. However, for the last six months, NSAIDs have not been able to stop the headache from getting worse. The headaches have improved when the medications were stopped. A probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Medication overuse headache.
 
  • Medication overuse headache occurs when a person takes too much medication for headaches. 
  • This can happen when a person takes over-the-counter pain relievers too often, or when a person takes prescription pain relievers more often than prescribed.
 
  • Symptoms: A daily headache that is worse in the morning, and a headache that does not respond to medication. 
  • The headache may also be accompanied by other symptoms, such as nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and noise.
  • In the case of the patient in the question, the patient has been taking analgesics on a regular basis for the past two years. The headaches have improved when the medications were stopped, which suggests that the headaches are caused by medication overuse.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3364.

choices.text: Admit in ICU and a manage without Invasive mechanical ventilation
Admit in ICU and manage with Invasive mechanical ventilation
Consider hospital admission in non ICU setting

questions.text: Male, age 68, coughing and producing sputum. Bronchial breath noises were audible during auscultation. No confusion. BP 110/70mm Hg, RR 20/min, and Urea 44. What action should be taken next?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Consider hospital admission in non ICU setting.

The CURB-65 score is a clinical score that is used to assess the severity of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). The score is based on the following factors:
  • Confusion
  • Urea level (>7 mmol/L)
  • Respiratory rate (>20 breaths/min)
  • Blood pressure (<90 mmHg systolic or <60 mmHg diastolic)
  • Age (>65 years)

 
  • The patient in the question has urea levels >7 mmol/ L and is aged >65. His CURB-65 score is 2, which indicates moderate CAP, therefore the treatment should be admission in a non-ICU setting.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1012.

questions.text: A patient went to the emergency room complaining of severe chest pain. He experienced a syncope episode with a brief loss of consciousness. The patient was diaphoretic and had obvious signs of instability. Uneven bilateral pulses were present. Tachycardia with non-specific ST-T alterations was seen on the ECG. Which of the following studies will serve as a roadmap for future management?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Aortic Dissection.
The clinical presentation and ECG revealing nonspecific ST-T changes strongly suggest aortic dissection. Given the patient’s hemodynamic instability, the next best investigation is a transesophageal echocardiogram.

Aortic Dissection:

Aortic dissection occurs when a tear or flap develops in the intima of the aorta, allowing blood to track into the aortic tissues and split the medial layer.

Predisposing Factors:
- Age
- Hypertension
- Marfan syndrome
- Pregnancy
- Other connective tissue disorders (e.g., Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, giant cell arteritis, systemic lupus erythematosus)
- Coarctation of the aorta
- Turner or Noonan syndromes
- Iatrogenic factors (e.g., aortic cannulation)

Clinical Features:
  • The hallmark presentation of aortic dissection is severe tearing pain between the shoulder blades, often accompanied by diaphoresis. Additional symptoms may include syncope, weakness, and dyspnea.
  • Physical examination may reveal hypertension or hypotension, loss of pulses, signs of aortic regurgitation, pulmonary edema, or neurological deficits. Unequal pulses or blood pressure in the limbs may indicate alterations in blood flow between the true and false lumens.
 
  • An endoscopic transducer is inserted into the esophagus during a typical transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE), a type of ultrasonography that provides a generally better view of the major vessels and posterior cardiac structures than the transthoracic method (TTE).
  • To evaluate cardiac and aortic structures, TOE is most frequently utilised in the fields of anesthesiology, cardiology, and critical care.
 
  • IOC in hemodynamically unstable patient: TEE
  • IOC in hemodynamically stable patient: CT angiography



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2104, 2105.

questions.text:
A 50 yr old male had been complaining of fatigue for a year. Evaluation revealed severe splenomegaly and moderate an++aemia.
Neutrophils make up 60% of the blood, whereas basophils and eosinophils make up 4%, 6%, and 15% of the lymphocytes, respectively. In PBS, Myeloblasts, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and bands were also seen. The M:E ratio is 18:1. What investigation is the most sensitive?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: FISH with PCR.
 
  • The patient's clinical presentation, including severe splenomegaly, moderate anemia, abnormal blood cell differentials, and an elevated M:E ratio of 18:1, strongly suggests Chronic myeloid leukemia.
 
  • FISH with PCR is a molecular cytogenetic technique used to detect specific chromosomal abnormalities or genetic mutations associated with myeloproliferative neoplasms.
Plan of action : -
Acute Leukemia - Bone Marrow Aspiration 
CML - FISH
CLL- Flow cytometry 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 820, 821.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old female patient with atrial fibrillation and mitral stenosis was diagnosed.
No thrombus is shown on the ECHO. Which of the following prevents stroke the best in feature?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Oral warfarin
 
  • Irregular heartbeats (atrial fibrillation) and narrowing of the mitral valve (mitral stenosis) can cause blood clots, posing a stroke risk.
  • Both conditions increase the risk of blood clot formation in the heart, which can potentially travel to the brain and cause a stroke.
  • In the absence of a thrombus on ECHO, the patient is at risk for developing a blood clot in the heart.
  • Oral Warfarin has been shown to be effective in preventing strokes in patients with atrial fibrillation and mitral stenosis.

Anticoagulation in atrial fibrillation:
Anticoagulation is indicated for patients with mitral stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, previous history of stroke. In nonvalvular atrial fibrillation, the risk of stroke and the need for anticoagulation is assessed with the CHA2DS2-VASc score.

Anticoagulants that can be used include:
  • Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
  • Antithrombin inhibitor - Dabigatran
  • Factor Xa inhibitors - Rivaroxaban, Apixaban, and Edoxaban
 
  • In AF patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves, the anticoagulant of choice is warfarin. The newer anticoagulants are not yet tested for rheumatic heart disease.
  • Warfarin is a less compliant drug because it requires routine PT/INR monitoring for dose adjustments and has many drug interactions. The newer oral anticoagulants are easy to use and do not require PT/INR monitoring for dose adjustments.



Anticoagulation in A. fib Trick- 
Valvular pathology- Warfarin
No valvular pathology- NOACs 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1906.

questions.text: A 68yr old female patient presented with Atrial fibrillation with Mitral stenosis. ECHO does not show any thrombus. Which among the following is the best to prevent stroke ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Warfarin

Anti coagulation is a very important part of the treatment of Atrial Fibrillation in order to prevent stroke.

Novel Oral anticoagulants like Dabigatran can generally be used for anti-coagulation in Atrial Fibrillation except the following: -
 
  • NOAC are contraindicated in patients with Mechanical prosthetic valves
  • NOAC are contraindicated in patients with Atrial Fibrillation in the backdrop of valvular heart disease like Moderate / Severe mitral stenosis
In such cases Warfarin can be used for the purpose of Anticoagulation.

* NOAC are preferred compared to Warfarin in case of stroke prevention in patients with Atrial Fibrillation who are at a high risk of Ischemic Stroke.

* A higher INR range (2.5–3.5) is recommended for patients with mechanical heart valves in the mitral position or for patients with mechanical valves in another position who have concomitant atrial fibrillation or a prior history of stroke.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 717.

questions.text: Patient had seizures, had a 24-hour urine output of 650 ml, had a urine osmolality of 1000 mOsm/kg, and had a serum osmolality of 270 mOsm/kg. What electrolyte anomaly can be anticipated after further examination?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from hyponatremia.
  • It is a disorder that develops when the blood's sodium content is unacceptably low.
  • The body retains too much water when this condition is present. Because of this, the blood's salt levels are diluted and fall. Nausea, headaches, disorientation, and weariness are symptoms.
  • There may be a need for restricted fluid consumption, medication, and hospitalisation.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 341-344.

questions.text: The fingertips of a female patient feel numb. Her skin was tighter on her face. A positive ANA result was obtained. The nucleolar pattern was seen using immunofluorescence. Which diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Systemic sclerosis
 
  • The condition is known as Systemic sclerosis (SS). This indicates that it is an autoimmune disease in which the body is attacked by the immune system. The immune system wrongly believes it to be a foreign material or illness, which causes healthy tissue to be destroyed. Many autoimmune illnesses exist that can impact various body systems.
  • Scleroderma patients frequently have a nucleolar pattern of ANA staining.
  • This patient also has Raynaud's phenomenon.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2772, 2776.

questions.text: Anti-emetics were administered to the patient who was vomiting. After the patient's symptoms were eased, strange motions later developed. What medication is recommended to lessen the movements?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Benzhexol

The given clinical vignette describes the condition called Drug induced Parkinsonism. Here in the question it has been mentioned that the patient was administered an anti emetic drug following which he/ she developed movements. This implies that the person was given D2 receptor antagonist ( Eg PROCHLORPERAZINE, METOCLOPRAMIDE ) as Anti emetic drug following which he developed extra pyramidal symptoms.

A general rule is that when the dopamine levels in brain falls as a reflex the cholinergic levels rise in our bodies. Hence the treatment of Drug induced parkinsonism involves the administration of drugs which can reduce the excess cholinergic activity.

* DOC FOR DRUG INDUCED PARKINSONISM/DRUG INDUCED DEVELOPMENT OF EXTRAPYRAMIDAL SYMPTOMS :- Benztropine, Trihexyphenidyl

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 460.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old male patient from Madhya Pradesh is experiencing leg stiffness and signs of increasing motor paresis.
What medical history will you review in order to make a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Diet history
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Neurolathyrism due to chronic intake of lathyrus sativus (Khesari dal).
 
  • Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. In the humans it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system
  • Neurolathyrism is a crippling disease of the nervous system characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of lower limbs, occurring mostly in adults consuming the pulse, Lathyrus sativus in large quantities. Neurolathyrism is prevalent in parts of Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Orissa
 
  • Lathyrus sativus is commonly known as "Khesari dhal". It is known by local names such as Teora dhal, Lak dhal
 
  • Studies have shown that diets containing over 30% of this dhal if taken over a period of 2—6 months will result in neurolathyrism.

Therefore, it is important to elicit dietary history in suspected case of Neurolathyrism.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 759.

questions.text:
A hysterical female patient was exhaling rapidly. She experienced carpopedal spasm. pH is 7.52, CO2 is 20, and HCO3 is 24 on ABG.
What is the abnormal acid-base condition?
questions.solution:
• This patient is suffering from respiratory alkalosis.
  • Decreased H+ ion concentration brought on by alkalosis causes more albumin to bind to calcium.
  • This results in lower levels of free calcium, which causes hypocalcemia and tetany in this patient.
Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 358.

questions.text: ESRD and pedal edema were detected in a patient with hypertension. The patient is reduced urine output. Investigations revealed that the serum creatinine level was 1.9 mg/dl. Which antihypertensive medication from the list below should be administered to this patient to treat their hypertension?
questions.solution:
#Controversial question 

The antihypertensive that can be given in this case is chlorthalidone. The patient in this case is having renal insufficiency but there is no proteinuria mentioned in the question stem. So among the given options, the thiazide diuretic chlorthalidone can be administered as antihypertensive in this patient.

Management of hypertension in chronic kidney disease(CKD):
 
  • ACE inhibitors or ARBs are considered the first-line drugs in patients with proteinuria.
  • These agents effectively reduce blood pressure, proteinuria and prevent kidney decline. Calcium channel blockers can be added if necessary.

For patients who do not have proteinuria, there is no established first-line therapy. One or two of the following drugs can be used:
  1. Thiazides/thiazide-like diuretics
  2. ACE inhibitors or ARBs
  3. Calcium channel blockers
  • In patients presenting with fluid retention or fluid overload, thiazide diuretics such as chlorthalidone and hydrochlorothiazide are recommended for management.
  • In CKD stages 1 to 3 (GFR thiazides are recommended, while loop diuretics such as bumetanide, furosemide are used in stages 4-5 (GFR < 30ml/min).


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 530, 610.
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 516.

questions.text: A patient with CKD is having a pyeloplasty. Which of the following post-operative analgesics is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
The medication that is frequently suggested for sporadic usage in people with renal disease is acetaminophen. It is safe in case of CKD. 
In comparison to intravenous paracetamol 1 gr and tramadol 0.7 mg/kg for patients undergoing renal surgery, various studies have shown that the combination of intravenous paracetamol 1 gr and ketamine 0.5 mg/kg resulted in a general reduction in pain scores, decreased postoperative analgesic requirements, and lower agitation score.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 2120.

questions.text:
A diabetic female patient who had previously eaten outside food was admitted with frequent vomiting.
BP is 90/60 mmHg. pH: 7.52. HCO3-  is 26.
PaCO2: 20+. Na-123, Potassium-3.2, and Chloride-67 meq/l are the electrolytes. What is the reason behind her ABG results?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Persistent vomiting.

The arterial blood gas (ABG) results show:
  1. pH: 7.52, indicating alkalosis as the pH is above the normal range (7.35-7.45).
  2. HCO3-: 26 mEq/L, showing elevated bicarbonate levels, which is a sign of metabolic alkalosis.
  3. PaCO2: 20+ mmHg, suggesting possible respiratory compensation for the metabolic alkalosis.
  • Based on the ABG results and low electrolyte levels, the most likely reason for her condition is persistent vomiting, leading to metabolic alkalosis. 
  • Vomiting causes loss of hydrochloric acid from the stomach, resulting in an alkalotic state.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 361, 365.

questions.text:
The patient has a history of mononeuritis multiplex, polymyalgia rheumatica, jaw claudication, headache, and giant cell arteritis.
What should the initial course of treatment be?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Prednisolone.

The patient is presenting with symptoms of giant cell arteritis (GCA), which is an inflammatory disease of the arteries. 

GCA can cause a number of symptoms, including:
  • Headache
  • Jaw claudication (pain in the jaw when chewing)
  • Polymyalgia rheumatica (pain and stiffness in the shoulders and hips)
  • Mononeuritis multiplex (inflammation of multiple nerves)
  • Amarausis fugax 
The initial course of treatment for GCA is high-dose prednisolone. It is especially important to start prednisolone as soon as GCA is suspected, due to the risk of vision loss by ophthalmic artery involvement.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2811, 2812.

questions.text:
A migrant worker arrived with complaints of burning urination and urethral discharge following a week of unprotected sex.
Which of the following organisms is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
• The given picture suggests gonorrhea infection.
  • Many gonorrhoea cases in men are asymptomatic.
  • When present, dysuria or a white, yellow, or green urethral discharge that typically emerges one to fourteen days after infection are among the indications and symptoms of urethral infection in males.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 30.3

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient arrived with skin lesions that are easily ruptureable and flaccid bullae. Suprabasal split was found after a biopsy. What diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
• Using histopathology, an intradermal blister is seen. The basal layer's intercellular edema and loss of intercellular linkages are the initial signs of alteration.
  • Clefts and blisters are created when suprabasal epidermal cells detach from the basal cells.
  • Although being divided from one another and arranged in a row on the blister's floor like tombstones, basal cells are still connected to the basement membrane. Certain acantholytic cells can be found in blister cells.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceous, which show a more superficial epidermal cleft, can be distinguished by histopathology.

Histology image of P. vulgaris. 



Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 47.1-47.5, 50.2-50.10.

questions.text: A leprosy patient who is multibacillary and receiving multiple medication therapies exhibits significant rashes on the lesions that are already present. He also displays neurological involvement. What comes next?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Continue ALT and start Steroids.
 
  • Rash or erythema in the existing lesion with nerve involvement suggest Type 1 Lepra reaction. It's a Type 4 Hypersensitivity reaction. ALT must be continue along with steroids as nerve involvement is present.
 
  • Type 1 lepra reactions involve inflammation of existing skin lesions, which become red, painful, and swollen, and may rarely ulcerate. Although new lesions can appear, they are uncommon. This reaction is associated with acute neuritis, including tenderness and loss of sensory and motor function.
 
  • For pain relief, NSAIDs can be added alongside oral steroids. Thalidomide is reserved for severe type 2 lepra reactions, or erythema nodosum leprosum, which involve systemic symptoms such as iritis, orchitis, and new skin lesion eruptions.




Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 28.5, 28,12, 28.16.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy presented to the OPD complaining of a mildly uncomfortable swelling on his scalp for the past three months.
She keeps a dog for a pet. What diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
• A fungal ringworm infection of the scalp's hair follicles (and occasionally the beard) that may be accompanied by a subsequent bacterial infection can cause kerion, an acute inflammatory condition.
  • It is caused by Trichophyton verrucosum and Microsporum canis. 
  • Mainly caused by fungus infecting animals, in the question pet dog is also mentioned. 
  • It typically affects children and manifests as elevated, spongy lesions.
  • This honeycomb-shaped inflammatory reaction causes excruciating agony and causes deep suppurative sores on the scalp. Pupillating follicles may be noticed.
Reference: Nakagawa H, Nishihara M, Nakamura T. Kerion and tinea capitis. IDCases. 2018 Jun 28;14:e00418. doi: 10.1016/j.idcr.2018.e00418. PMID: 29988774; PMCID: PMC6031098.

questions.text: Which of the following are tested using Hair perforation test?
questions.solution:
• Dermatophytes, particularly Trichophyton mentagrophytes and its variations, are tested for using a hair perforation test.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.27

questions.text:
A girl child was seen with the following lesion associated with dry eyes, and night blindness .
What does the dermatological finding in the picture represent?
questions.solution:
• This is a Phrynoderma case.
  • A type of follicular hyperkeratosis called phrynoderma is connected to nutritional deficits.
  • Although uncommon in developed nations, it is endemic among poor populations.
Nicholls first used the term "phrynoderma" to describe the "toad-like" appearance of the skin of malnourished labourers in 1933.
Isolated vitamin A, B complex, C, and E deficiency can result in this type of dermatosis

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 87.14

questions.text:
A patient's right upper limb has linear wheals in addition to having pain and edoema in the finger.
Which of the following antibiotics is best for treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Amoxiclav

The given clinical vignette describes skin and soft tissue infection characterized by linear wheals along with pain and oedema of finger for which Amoxiclav is the best drug.

AMOXYCLAV= AMOXICILLIN + CLAVULINIC ACID

Amoxicillin (penicillinase sensitive penicillin) destroys the bacteria and clavulanic acid being a Beta lactamase inhibitor prevents the destruction of Amoxicillin.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 774.

questions.text: While therapy session a therapist developed unconscious and conscious feelings towards the patient . What is it called?
questions.solution:
• Counter-transference, according to psychoanalytic theory, is when the therapist projects their own unresolved conflicts onto the client.
  • This can be a reaction to information the customer has discovered. Although many now see countertransference as inevitable, it can still be harmful if not handled properly.
  • Countertransference can be a result of unresolved personal issues or unresolved feelings towards previous patients. It can hinder the therapist's objectivity and ability to empathize with the patient.
  • Therefore, it is important for therapists to recognize and manage their countertransference reactions to prevent it from interfering with the therapeutic process.
  • Transference is feeling of patient towards doctors. 


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 866, 867.

questions.text: Which illness falls under the category of formal thought disorder?
questions.solution:
• Types of thought disorder include
  1. derailment,
  2. Pressured speech, 
  3. poverty of speech,
  4. Tangentiality,
  5. Verbigeration and
  6. Thought blocking.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 202, 228, 418.

questions.text: The patient, a 16-year-old female, had overfamiliarity, a struggle with thoughts, a high mood, heightened sexual drive, and pseudo hallucinations. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• Mania is a mental illness that results in unjustified euphoria, extremely intense feelings, hyperactivity, and delusions.
  • A typical bipolar disorder symptom is mania (or manic episodes). For a number of reasons, mania can be a dangerous condition.
  • During having a manic episode, some people may not eat or sleep.
  • Hypomania, is a less severe form of mania characterized by similar symptoms but with less intensity and duration.  
  • Cyclothymia, is a mood disorder characterized by chronic fluctuations in mood that are not severe enough to meet the criteria for bipolar disorder.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 292, 293, 348, 358.

questions.text: Following repeated appeals from his family, a chronic alcoholic male, age 53, made an effort to cut down on his drinking. After developing uneasiness, he was sent to the hospital on day three with altered sensory perception, confusion, anger, paranoid delusions, and visual hallucinations. Which of these is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The most severe type of ethanol withdrawal, known as delirium tremens, is characterised by altered mental status (generalised disorientation), sympathetic overdrive (autonomic hyperactivity), and circulatory collapse.
  • The symptoms of mild alcohol withdrawal include trembling, anxiety, nausea, vomiting, and insomnia.
  • Visual and auditory hallucinations, whole-body tremor, vomiting, diaphoresis, and hypertension are the main signs and symptoms of alcohol withdrawal.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 630. 631.

questions.text: A teacher demonstrated how to wash your hands. Students studied at home and practised. What domain of learning does it fit under?
questions.solution:
Hand hygiene is a psychomotor skill that requires thinking and making motor movements to achieve a task.

Cognitive- deals with learning skills
Affective- deals with emotions


Reference: https://www.britannica.com/science/psychomotor-learning
